Juego terminado el 21/11/23 dificultad: difícil. 

IMPORTANTE: Mi reseña del juego ya está escrita en el juego original, aquí solo voy hablar del rendimiento y el contenido extra.

- Rendimiento: Esta versión funciona peor que el juego original, menos mal que al comprarlo te ambas versiones, por algún motivo esta versión tiene un framerate inestable; el juego anterior lo pude jugar a 120hz sin problemas, en esta a cada rato tenia caidas a 100 - 90 fps y sin importar la taza fijada, cuando colocaba el juego a solo 60hz entonces tenia caidas a 30 - 50 fps, busqué en foros y al parecer es un problema de optimización, una pena la verdad, el juego es muy bueno, pero la edición completa va muy mal

- Extra: el contenido extra son pequeños añadidos que enriquecen la historia y la jugabilidad del juego base, con mas historia de un personaje principal, nuevas habilidades y zonas nuevas, además de una mayor dificultad.

Conclusión
Si quieres jugar el contenido completo, juega esta versión, pero ten en cuenta que va regular de rendimiento, si quieres estabilidad, juega el juego base, ese va perfecto.

150459603.review:
Save yourself the frustration and watch someone else complete this game.  The graphics and soundtrack along with how Ori looks while escaping areas in this game are definitely worth watching without all the death frustrations.

Exploring in this game was very frustrating because I was constantly dying in one hit.  Once I learned how to get past this spot I would die at the next spot within less than five minutes.  This cycle continued repeatedly over and over again.  I wish there was some breathing room in between these deaths to enjoy exploring this beautiful game.  Ori would also sometimes not perform certain actions at critical moments leading to more deaths.  I also do not like it when these deaths are related to something that was off screen or very hard to see.  It feels cheap and adds to the frustration.  

Combat was boring.  Only one button to press for a limited range homing projectile to attack a random enemy.  There were also no bosses to do combat with.  Escaping seemed to be the bosses.  Ability upgrades were also generic and did not add much to the game-play.

Overall I was more frustrated getting through this game rather than having fun.  I was given the next Ori game as a gift and heard it improves a lot from the shortcomings of this game.  Watch and enjoy someone else complete this game and then play the next Ori game.

150272443.review:
The story, the music, the graphics...it's a work of art. There's a reason people are still playing this game, even 8 years after release. It holds up.

That said, there are also parts of it I found to be incredibly un-fun. While easy mode is certainly *easier*, it's not *easy*. At all. The main advantages of easy mod are that:

-Resources (spirit light, energy, life) are more abundant, and upgrades cost less (helpful for sure)
- Enemies have less health and deal less damage, but there are still looooots of enemies/obstacles that will kill you instantly. Overall, i found the combat difficulty to be easy even as someone who doesn't usually play these sorts of games, but then you land on a spike and you have to do it all over again anyway.
-  The boss sequences (e.g. [spoiler] escaping the ginso tree, battling kuro, etc [/spoiler]) have a checkpoint in the middle so you don't have to do the entire thing in one go.

TL;DR: this game requires a lot of precision (often under time pressure), and the sheer frustration of some sequences made me question why I was willingly doing this with my free time. But the story and the world are truly magnificent, and that's what kept me coming back.

What I like about Ori and the Blind Forest:
- Low emphasis on combat (which is especially interesting in combination with the metroidvania structure)
- Focus on horizontal movement
- Lavish audiovisual presentation
- Solid and balanced metroidvania progression
- Fairly light-hearted setting (reminds me of Celeste)
- High production value
- Relatively short playtime

The only substantial flaw is that the combat is often tedious. I often found myself mashing a button and waiting for an enemy to succumb.

149807108.review:
Al ser este mi juego favorito, probablemente nuble un tanto mi visión crítica, pero intentaré dar la reseña mas objetiva posible.

Como recomendación para cualquier persona que planee jugar Ori es desvincularla de Hollow Knigth. Es un juego maravilloso, eso está claro, pero si comparamos cada juego metroidvania con éste, nadie se sentiría satisfecho porque no llenaría sus expectativas. Ori no es Hollow Knigth, y eso no va a cambiar.

Para iniciar mi reseña (y esto es algo que dudo que alguien me vaya a discutir) el OST es maravilloso. Es mágico e inmersivo, además de que busca innovar en algunos detalles (Un ejemplo de esto es que uno de sus temas está hecho con la escala Hexáfona). Es fabuloso cada detalle de su banda sonora, y por momentos cuando estoy jugando simplemente quiero ir a abrazar a Gareth Coker y agradecerle por existir.

En cuanto al apartado visual, aunque considero que su secuela hizo un mejor trabajo, no creo que esté mal en lo absouto. Ninguna parte de los fondos o diseños luce fuera de lugar, y la iluminación me parece fantástica.

La historia, por otro lado, se me hace simple de entender, y el enemigo es un personaje con el cual se puede empatizar. Además, tener a sein como un guia, pero que no está constantemente hablando y molestando (Como personajes al estilo Paimon, que buscan guiar pero llegado un punto se vuelven irritantes)

Para finalizar, la jugabilidad es super interesante. Aunque sea una fórmula basica de todos los metroidvania y prácticamente no innovar en el tema, todas las mecánicas se me hacen divertidas, permitiendome volver al inicio del juego y acceder a zonas que permanecían ocultas o lejanas hasta el momento.

Recomiendo este juego a cualquier persona que disfrute de una banda sonora inmersiva, los metroidvania, o simplemente apartados visuales lindos.

149327518.review:
Stop browsing. Buy this game RIGHT NOW. Then go and buy its sequel (Ori and the Will of the Wisps).

This is one of those games that kinda peaked my interest because I love metroidvania's. So, I bought it, put it in my "I'll get to it later pile" and left it there for years..... what a mistake that was. I cannot believe how long I waited to play this masterpiece. And that IS what this is, a MASTERPIECE and so is its sequel.

I won't spoil the story here but I will say that this game is all about loss and dealing with loss. While there are moments of true sadness (this is one of 3 games ever to bring me to legitimate tears, The Last of Us and Mass Effect 3 [Mordin!!!] being the others) but it is so much more than that!

Gameplay - A masterclass in metroidvania design. Exploration, discovery and character advancement and development are at their best here. Combat is very well done. Simple but still possesses depth. Challenging but  not overly so. It's definitely not Soulslike levels of challenging. But it is also rewarding and rarely feels unfair. Movement (especially late game with some added abilities) is seriously satisfying. 

Graphics - Incredible! Beautiful! The art style perfectly compliments what this game is trying to achieve and accentuates the themes and mood that permeate every aspect of this game. There are also some seriously breathtaking set pieces on display here.

Music & Sound - The sounds are completely adequate. More than is needed for a game of this type. The music is again, best in class. Yet another example of a perfect pairing between theme and mood to fit the game. I love it so very much.

Rating: 10/10

I don't know what else needs to be said. This game is a must buy. My wife even loved watching me play it and she has a hate for all video games that goes down to her very core. Just buy the game already. You won't regret it at all.

149288368.review: One of the best 2D games out there, 10/10

149278233.review:
It's really hard to recommend this game when Hollow Knight came out 2 years later and improved on every single aspect of the genre. I know it's not fair to review an older game using a newer game as comparison, but after playing Hollowed Knight, you realize just how absolutely annoying every enemy in Ori is and how it is a chore instead of fun fighting them. Also, your one main attack is one that you constantly have to button spam; no just holding down the attack button because we are apparently going back to the 80s Nintendo days. The only reason why the game doesnt let you to just hold down the attack button is because it would just reveal how weak the combat is; since there is never a moment in the game where you shouldnt be attacking and there's no punishment for always attacking regardless of the enemy and situation, the game would just devolve into holding down the attack button from the moment the game starts to the moment the game ends.

The level designs way overuse floor spikes, with many of them impossible to see until you land on them and will immediately end your run. Levels are not designed in such a way that they are fun to explore, because they are not made so that the players intuitively know where to go next, and it's never clear if you are in the right area the game wants you to be or if you are in an area that is designed to come back at a later time. And before someone calls me a casual, understand that every single game with deep exploration and branching paths, even Dark Souls, cleverly tricks and guide the player into going where the player needs to go next, in such a subtle way that the player doesnt even realize it. This game doesnt know how to do that at all.

It's objectively not a bad game; it just doesnt deserve its overwhelming score.

149150269.review:
A platforming-centric metroidvania with the worst combat I have ever experienced.

Pros
-The artwork is phenomenal.
-The bash mechanic.
-Good to great music.

Cons
-The combat is miserable. Mash X to fire glowing blobs while enemies try to ram you or fire their own glowing blobs back (some of the enemies are basically just glowing blobs).
-Visual clarity is awful. So many enemies, items, and attacks in this game are glowing blobs that things can get confusing pretty quickly in combat. Also, sometimes the background/environmental art gets in the way of gameplay.
-The story loses any sense of weight once resurrection gets involved.
-Their is no fast travel mechanic so if you want to go around the map and get all the secrets you missed/were unable to get earlier you need to walk there.
-The mist woods as an area is kind of a pain in the ass.
-Can't disable help/tool-tip popups (reminding you that you have an upgrade point, etc) and they sometimes interfere with gameplay by obscuring platforms, enemies, etc.
-Sound effects are bland to annoying for enemies/combat.
-Music  and sound effects get way too loud in the chase sequences.
-Buttons on the controller cannot be remapped.

Neutral
-You have a Navi but it is less annoying.
-Controller vibration is crazy, I strongly recommend turning it dowm.

Probably one of the best platformers ever made. The visuals are astonishing, the soundtrack is very immersive, and although the game mechanics aren't as complex and balanced as its successor's (Will of the Wisps) (i.e. most of the game is all about spamming attacks and saving every 2 seconds), the gameplay is still really enjoyable.
Achievement grinding is fun too. Some of them are really challenging and rewarding.
I haven't played the "non-" Definitive Edition so I don't exactly know what changed between 2015 and today, but if I'm not mistaken they added some behind-the-scenes content to watch from the main menu, with an extra chapter at the end of the game's story - also a blast to play, and a very nice addition to the game.
Props to Moon Studios for releasing this masterpiece back in 2015. Wish I knew about it back then! I'd give it a solid 9/10. (Again, not 10/10 because of the repetitive combat mechanics unfortunately.)
Thanks for reading.

148733831.review:
I'm very much in two minds about this game. On one hand it's beautiful to look at, has an incredible score and a well-presented story: clearly a lot of love has gone into its development. Unfortunately I also found it very awkward to actually play it. For a start, Ori controls like he is on ice the entire time. Coming from just having played Hollow Knight, it just feels so floaty and imprecise and it's sometimes very frustrating to pull off the platforming needed in the more difficult sections because of this. When you die in Hollow Knight, you feel like it was your fault every time because of the tight controls, but it can feel unfair sometimes here.

My other complaint is about the game backgrounds. They are very busy and the edges between background and foreground are not always clear: to the point where you have to keep a very sharp eye out for spikes and other hazards. It's also hard sometimes to differentiate between pickups, the light that buzzes around Ori and enemy projectiles. I feel like I should really enjoy it, being a big Metroidvania and platforming fan, but these issues got in the way too much that I found it more annoying than fun

148673231.review: This game sure is a mixed bag. While it boasts stunning visuals, the gameplay falls a bit flat. The character movement lacks precision, coming off as floaty. The save system is peculiar; there are times when you can frequently save your progress, and other times when you're left wanting. Intriguingly, the game uses the same currency for saving, opening gates, and executing powerful attacks. This system might have been tolerable if the health mechanism was effective. However, the game is riddled with instant death attacks, thrusting you back to your last save point. It almost feels as if this was their solution to complaints about the sudden death challenges. In the few hours I played, my feelings alternated between genuine enjoyment and sheer annoyance due to some design choices.

148647048.review:
"Ori and the Blind Forest" is a mesmerizing and emotionally charged platform that stands as a work of art in the gaming world. This enchanting adventure, developed by Moon Studios, takes players on a captivating journey through a lush and mysterious forest.

Visually, the game is a masterpiece. The hand-drawn art style and attention to detail create a stunning and immersive world. The forest's beauty is juxtaposed with its danger, giving the game a unique atmosphere that keeps players engaged and in awe.

The game play is equally impressive. The platforming mechanics are tight and intuitive, offering challenging yet satisfying experiences as you navigate through the forest's perilous terrain. As Ori, the game's agile protagonist, you'll unlock new abilities and upgrades that keep the game play fresh and exciting.

One of the game's standout features is its storytelling. "Ori and the Blind Forest" weaves a touching and emotionally resonant narrative as it explores themes of friendship, sacrifice, and the power of determination. The characters, particularly Ori and Sein, are endearing, and players become deeply invested in their journey.

Gareth Coker's musical score is a perfect companion to the game's visual and emotional elements. The music sets the tone beautifully, enhancing the emotional impact of the story and the game play.

While the game is a true gem, it's not without its challenges. Some players might find its difficulty level to be on the high side, with certain sections requiring precise timing and quick reflexes. However, this difficulty adds to the sense of accomplishment when you overcome obstacles.

In conclusion, "Ori and the Blind Forest" is a must-play title for fans of platforms, artful storytelling, and immersive experiences. It's a visually stunning, emotionally engaging game that leaves a lasting impression. This game is not just a gaming experience; it's a work of art that showcases the potential of the medium.

147991072.review:
A decently challenging platformer with some creative mechanics built into its powerup system. The music is pretty and the environments and puzzles can be quite creative, but I find myself distinctly un-immersed. 

The game balance shifts from careful save energy management to just letting you drop a save point after every jump so rapidly that it feels like the game's only way to compensate is to throw more no-mercy challenges at you to kill you with a single mistake. It could have easily had you respawn at the last safe platform when you fall into a pit, but instead it forces you to save literally everywhere just in case some bullshit enemy is around the next corner and one-shots you and your pitiful health pool. Not helped by the fact that sometimes its difficult to tell what's in the foreground and whats a danger on your plane of movement, or the fact that all the blurry light particles flying around sometimes makes it difficult to tell what's a threat in time to dodge it.

And the story, while presenting a veneer of wholesome adventure about love and family, falls apart at any level of scrutiny. It feels like the morals of the story are that it's fine to behave with reckless disregard for others' safety if you miss someone (whom you've never properly met), choosing found family over biological family is a mistake, anger over legitimate wrongs done to your family is bad if the target of your anger is more important than you, and so on. The narration literally calls the Ori's decision to stay with their adoptive parent a "mistake" about 15 minutes of gameplay away from revealing that [spoiler]the light that called Ori to their biological home had repercussions that killed literally everyone who journeyed to that location.[/spoiler]

147969684.review:
This is a tough one to choose between recommending or not. On one hand it's a great atmospheric platformer with some interesting twists on the genre, the biggest one for me being no boss battles, but on the other I kept getting to a point where the game stopped being fun because of...

Chase sequences, there are just too many of them, combined with unforgiving error margins and inconsistent enemy/projectile I ended up being happy when they were over rather than feeling accomplished for having beaten them.

YMMV and if you love long combos of twitchy platforming there's hardly anything to fault.

147750343.review:
Ori and The Blind Forest

8.5/10

I really enjoyed the platforming and levels are well designed, where they it is easy to tell where you need to go next for your quest. For main quest, there is no need to backtrack to places been to b4 just to use the new skills unlocked to help in reaching areas unreachable without. this is because in every new level, corresponding skills needed to clear it is given and thus ur able to clear it without needing to return to other areas just to clear the game

Movement is smooth and input are very responsive especially since some levels require minor jumps etc. This allows for a more smooth gameplay experience. Difficulty is appropriate where even a newbie player like me can easily clear the hard difficulty. the ability to put your own checkpoint is a very good feature, allowing you to plan your gameplay yourself and do trial and error of levels more efficiently

However, despite all the good points, players should take note that after every clear of a level, there is a final part that is like challenging a boss fight, which in this case is escaping from a natural disaster of a element, eg water, and since you cant use checkpoints, you are required to clear it in one go which can be frustrating as some can be difficult and long. Butttt, do not fret for there will be only 3-4 of them in the whole game so overall your experience will still be a fun one

Also, the music and visuals are out of this world!!! They are very beautiful and you will find yourself just enjoying the view. Plus storytelling is great, with all the right visuals and music to complement, its a 10/10 masterpiece for the visual and music department!! They did a really good job!!

147287017.review:
Apparently Ori gets brought up whenever video games as art is discussed. I understand that it's a beautiful game with a memorable soundtrack. The themes are there and the characters get introduced in a natural way without too much explaining.

However, art or not, it's still a video game. I want to play it. The very first moment I get the control of the intro character, I want to see what happens when I try to walk off a ledge. You cannot, there's an invisible wall. It's a minor flaw (barely a flaw at all) but personally it's infuriating and lazy design. You want to put a mandatory slow walking introduction but you don't want to think outside the box [i]at all[/i]? You could easily put an alternative hidden route there and you don't need an invisible wall. Art games and invisible walls, Mona Lisa and rotten teeth.

Not to mention Ori's very much a game for kids (and manchildren). If I was under 15 I could see it becoming a favourite. The story seems simple and effective and the visuals kick ass.

How about the gameplay? Brace your mouse arm to get tendonitis because you are going to mash the mouse button for a ridiculous amount of time. For the short while I played the enemies got noticeably more bullet-spongy and every time you plan to hit an enemy once, it's one mouse click. I see no reason for it, you could easily just hold the mouse button to fire continuously. Wall jumping controls felt awkward and most of the reviews state that the end game platforming gets more and more difficult.

I'll leave this one to people who instantly want to immerse themselves into Ori. I'm just a cynic who wished the whole intro sequence for the fat kidnapper to die off.

A great storm separates a newborn spirit named Ori from the Spirit Tree that protects the forest of Nibel. Adopted by a curious creature named Naru, she quickly takes the role of a loving adoptive mother and cares for Ori as they grow up. Life is peaceful and idyllic until one fateful summer when a strange darkness creeps in and twists the forest, withering the fruit trees and poisoning the water, bringing famine and death. Newly orphaned, Ori flees from their home and meets a mysterious light named Sein who knows why the forest has changed - and needs Ori's help restoring it to its natural order.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3035299427
9-40+ hours to complete, Ori and the Blind Forest is a fantasy metroidvania RPG with puzzles and platforming. This game is difficult. In my first playthrough on Hard mode, I died over 400 times and truly didn’t enjoy playing until after the first “dungeon”, The Ginso Tree, where the world suddenly opens up after gaining vital movement skills. Regardless, this game is a genuinely wonderful experience that I wish many more people would play. The story was handled amazingly well despite having such little dialogue. Areas are fun to explore, and you are frequently rewarded for your curiosity with lots of hidden places and secrets to find. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3034748860

147162319.review:
[h1]"Ori and the Blind Forest"[/h1]
[b]es un verdadero tesoro en el mundo de los videojuegos, un título que brilla con luz propia y que se ha ganado un lugar especial en el corazón de los amantes de los juegos de estilo metroidvania. Desarrollado por Moon Studios y publicado por Microsoft Studios, este juego es un testimonio del poder del arte, la narrativa y la jugabilidad en la industria de los videojuegos. Es difícil exagerar la calidad y la belleza que este título ofrece a los jugadores, y en esta reseña, exploraremos a fondo por qué Ori merece un lugar destacado entre los mejores juegos del género.

Desde el primer momento en que se inicia el juego, se siente una inmersión absoluta en un mundo de fantasía magníficamente detallado y diseñado. La narrativa de Ori es conmovedora y emotiva, llevando a los jugadores a través de una historia de amor, sacrificio y redención. Nos sumergimos en el papel de Ori, una pequeña criatura luminosa que debe emprender un viaje épico para salvar el Bosque Ciego de una inminente destrucción. La trama se desarrolla de manera sutil y efectiva, sin necesidad de un diálogo extenso, ya que la narración visual y la música excepcional hablan por sí mismas.

El apartado visual de Ori and the Blind Forest es sencillamente deslumbrante. Cada cuadro parece una obra de arte en movimiento, con un estilo de dibujo a mano que le da vida al mundo del juego de una manera que pocos títulos logran igualar. Los colores vibrantes y los contrastes entre la luz y la oscuridad son una delicia para los ojos, y el nivel de atención al detalle es asombroso. Cada rincón del Bosque Ciego está lleno de vida, desde las majestuosas ramas de los árboles hasta las criaturas diminutas que pululan por el entorno. La animación es fluida y realista, lo que contribuye a que la experiencia sea aún más inmersiva.

La música es otro aspecto en el que Ori brilla con luz propia. La banda sonora, compuesta por Gareth Coker, es un acompañamiento emocional perfecto para la historia y el entorno. Cada pieza musical se adapta perfectamente a la atmósfera del juego, ya sea en los momentos más emotivos o en las frenéticas secuencias de plataformas. La música es capaz de hacerte sentir la tristeza, la alegría y la tensión a medida que avanzas en la historia. Es un logro musical que merece reconocimiento por sí mismo.

La jugabilidad es donde Ori and the Blind Forest se destaca aún más. El juego combina elementos de plataformas, exploración y resolución de acertijos de manera magistral. El movimiento de Ori es suave y ágil, lo que permite a los jugadores realizar acrobacias y movimientos precisos. A medida que avanzas en el juego, desbloqueas nuevas habilidades que expanden tus capacidades y te permiten explorar áreas previamente inaccesibles. La curva de dificultad es perfecta, desafiante pero justa, lo que te obliga a mejorar tus habilidades sin caer en la frustración.

Los acertijos y los desafíos de plataformas están perfectamente integrados en el diseño del mundo. Cada área presenta un conjunto único de desafíos que requieren ingenio y habilidad para superar. La sensación de logro al superar un área difícil o resolver un enigma complicado es inmensa y gratificante. Además, el juego te permite guardar en cualquier momento, lo que evita la frustración de repetir secciones difíciles una y otra vez.

Otro aspecto que merece mención especial es la progresión del personaje y la personalización. A medida que avanzas en la historia, puedes mejorar las habilidades de Ori y adaptar su estilo de juego a tu preferencia. Esto añade una capa adicional de profundidad a la jugabilidad y te permite abordar los desafíos de diferentes maneras.

En cuanto a la duración, Ori and the Blind Forest ofrece una experiencia que puede variar desde 8 a 12 horas, dependiendo de tu estilo de juego y de cuánto te detengas a explorar y recolectar secretos. Esta duración es perfecta para sumergirte en el mundo de Ori sin sentir que el juego se alarga innecesariamente. [/b]

146805024.review:
I wish I could like it.  But I don't.

I've played 2D platformers for years.  Decades, really.  Metriod, Zelda, and Mario; Castlevania; Mega Man, and the wide plethora of knockoffs.  I wouldn't brag, but I certainly would categorize myself as reasonably competent.

This game's gorgeous graphics pulled me in right away.  The plot, while simplistic, was captivating.  The intro was moving, even.  And off I went, to solve puzzles, earn experience, and gain power-ups, all the while keeping a weathered eye on my mana and life totals.  Very throwback; very classic; with a touch of newness.  I was hooked.  Oh, look; an [obstacle] that I can't circumvent; surely therefore I'll find [power-up] to help me with that, later on.  Don't forget it's there!  Probably something juicy behind it!

Then I started encountering some more challenging areas.  More difficult enemies.  More convoluted jumping around.  Eh, no problem.  Just takes getting used to.  I got used to Mario.  I'll get used to this guy.  That's part of the fun; it's a puzzle world, filled with danger, interlaced in jumping around challenges.  If you like that sort of thing.  And I do!  So I pressed on.

Then I started encountering some *really* challenging areas.  Skin-of-your-teeth jumps.  Unforgiving monsters.  But you can save your game almost anywhere.  So repeating attempts is not that inconvenient.  Aside from the tedium and frustration of attempting the same series of jumps, dodges, and attacks over and over until you've circumvented the situation.  Only to find a similar scenario right around the corner.  Hrmph.  But hey, that's, uh, still part of the fun, heh, right?  It's a challenge!  It's uh... it's an experience!  Something to relish when you finally triumph!  Yeah, that's it!

Then I started encountering some really, REALLY challenging courses.  Like, five or more absolutely flawlessly timed jumps in sequence, in different directions; or instant death.  Ouch.  And you know what?  After my eleventeenth attempt, it just stopped being fun.  Mind you, I'm only a small fraction of the way through the game at this point.  And I'm already frustrated beyond my tolerance point -- which, I really do want to say, is pretty flexible when it comes to these sorts of games.

Since I'm throwing the game under the bus, at this point I'll also mention its somewhat silly experience point system.  It'd pretty easy to farm exp if you really wanted to, since if you walk five steps off the screen after defeating a big, fat monster, you can walk back and find that big, fat monster has respawned.  And it has three talent trees (well, lines), but the trees are locked against acquiring various power-ups, so you end up just spending points in all three lines anyway.

Perhaps it's harsh; it is, after all, just a 2D platformer.  But the level of challenge it presents reminds me of a sugar-hyped-up pre-teen bulding the "Ult1m4t3 M4r10 Ch4ll3ng3 L0L", where you have to jump perfectly nineteen times in eleven different directions at just the right moment or you die and start over.  It gets old fast.

145877448.review:
Do I recommend this game? Yes, but this is one of the cases where I kind of regret there is no mixed button on Steam for reviews. It is one of the most visually stunning games I have had the pleasure of playing, the art style is great, the sound fits the game very well, the story while simple is told in a way to evoke very powerful feelings and the basic platforming is very very enjoyable. What is my problem with the game then? Simple, it is the chase scenes and I will try to explain why.

First of all to understand my point of view, you have to think where platformers started. They were made to be arcade games where every try cost you a quarter (or an equivalent), thus the games were made to be hard, but if you yourself got better at the game you could definitely feel it throughout the game. Also there was no cheap difficulty of having to replay the level several times to know exactly where damage will come from, since it would have been a blatant money grab. In this game death means nothing (except for a waste of time), but the frustration lingers.

Now imagine two worlds, in one world the difficulty of chase scene is dynamic, meaning no matter how well you executed the first part of the chase scene, it gives you nothing. No additional time whatsover. Thus the whole chase scene is just a series of precisely executed moves, that even if you make just a small mistake at the end, means you are replaying the whole thing again. When you finally finish the scene, you are not happy you did so, you feel relieved.

In the other world, the chase scene itself is on a timer. After several tries you execute the first half of the chase extremely and you have some stumbles in the second half, but since you did so well in the first half you manage to recover from your mistakes and eventually finish the whole. You feel proud of your accomplishment, because you steadily got better, you saw the progression and even if you stumbled a few times along the road, the fact that you got better managed to carry you through the whole thing.

I am fairly sure you know which of these worlds you would prefer and which of these worlds you will encounter in this game. The chase scenes in this game are not a challenge, they are an inconvenience.

144582486.review:
If you like Apple products, I imagine you'll like this game. If they annoy you like they do me, maybe think twice before picking it up.

Ori and the Blind Forest offers a certain experience, and it just wasn't for me. I enjoyed most of my time with it. It was fun - not necessarily amazing, but good. But over and over, I found myself getting annoyed by small things - unclear mechanics, puzzles that require you to do something you've never done before, the fact that you can practically softlock yourself by saving deep in enemy territory with low health (you respawn with the same amount of health you save with). Individually, they wouldn't be a big deal, but there were a lot of them, and they added up.

Tangent (no spoilers): [spoiler]That last one might sound like something you'd only do on purpose, but because you can save anywhere [i]and the game is designed around you being able to do that[/i], it's easy to repeatedly save with a little less health and a little more progress and run out of health before you reach the next heal. It is possible to reload a previous save, but it's really not obvious that it's an option, and in my opinion it's a mistake that it has to be an option at all.[/spoiler]

The best analogy I can think of is Apple products vs Android/Windows/Linux. Apple products are smooth, sleek, and easy to use by default, but a lot of people dislike them because (among other reasons) there are so many limitations and lack of advanced features/customization/tweakability. If you want something to just work with as little effort on your part as possible, I would guess you like Apple products (a totally valid opinion), but if you want it to work [i]well[/i], I'd imagine you prefer to avoid them (which is where I personally stand).

Ori and the Blind Forest is the embodiment of an Apple product here. It does an amazing job at the aesthetics - everyone says it's a beautiful game, and I agree. I just wish it didn't come at the cost of everything else.

144528369.review:
This is a difficult game (I'm bad at platformers so it might not be if you're really good at them) but it's not a punishing game. In fact it is quite forgiving of mistakes due to your ability to save almost everywhere. There are a few very difficult sequences where you're allowed only one or two mistakes during the whole thing, but its so satisfying when you beat it. Once you get the muscle memory for each sequence it becomes a lot easier as well. 

I love the art, the music is phenomenal, and while its not the most deep story, it is emotional. This is a very good game.

Side note, once you get good at the game, you realize the game is actually quite short. This isnt a criticism, just an observation.

"Ori and the Blind Forest" es una obra maestra que cautiva desde el primer momento con su belleza visual y emotiva narrativa. Este juego logra combinar a la perfección la estética artística con una jugabilidad fluida y desafiante, creando una experiencia única que deja una huella duradera en los corazones de los jugadores.

Desde el momento en que se inicia el juego, los gráficos deslumbrantes y el estilo de animación meticulosamente detallado capturan la atención. Los paisajes pintados a mano y los personajes adorables están llenos de vida y personalidad, sumergiendo a los jugadores en un mundo mágico y envolvente.

Pero "Ori and the Blind Forest" no se trata solo de una apariencia impresionante; su jugabilidad es igualmente impresionante. La mezcla de plataformas desafiantes, rompecabezas ingeniosos y habilidades evolutivas del personaje proporciona una experiencia de juego diversa y satisfactoria. Cada nuevo poder adquirido por Ori abre un abanico de posibilidades, permitiendo a los jugadores abordar los desafíos de formas creativas y gratificantes.

La narrativa del juego es otro de sus puntos destacados. La historia de amor, sacrificio y superación es contada de manera conmovedora, evocando una gama de emociones que van desde la alegría hasta la tristeza. Acompañada por una magnífica banda sonora que acentúa cada momento clave, la experiencia se vuelve aún más inmersiva y emotiva.

RECOMENDADO 100%

My review of Ori and the Blind Forest:

Full Rating: 9/10
Being a massive hollow knight and metroidvania fan, this comes as no surprise. I absolutely adored this game, and while I went through it pretty quickly, my 14 hours of gameplay were a very memorable and enjoyable experience.

Visuals: 10/10
The visuals in this game could not be more perfect. Everything is lively and detailed and every area is unique. I don't have much else to say besides that, the graphics are just really good.

Soundtrack: 8/10
The soundtrack provided some nice ambience and added a lot to the game, it just simply isn't something I'd actively listen to on it's own. Still really good tho, just not on the level of games like hollow knight

Story: 8/10
While not as complicated and heavy as some other games out there, I liked the basic story, and it was honestly quite beautiful.

Gameplay: 10/10
The gameplay in this was honestly fantastic. The movement was super fluid and once you collect all the abilities moving around is super satisfying. My favorite parts were escaping the ...temples?? I honestly have no idea what they're called. 

Replayability: 6/10
Honestly games like this don't tend to be very replayable, however the different difficulties provide a challenge that deffinitley adds to its replayability

Extra Notes:
Overall I really enjoyed this game, and I'm excited to dive into the sequel. If you like a good metroidvania, give this one a try.

143338657.review:
firstly, this game is absolutely beautiful and i wholly recommend it.

now, while i loved this game, i have to say i feel like will of the wisps is just all around more polished and in depth. though, i strongly urge that you play blind forest first even still as it is a great game in its own right and has a beautiful story that greatly enhances the experience of will of the wisps' own story... as sequential stories tend to do lol

the main focus of the gameplay is 2d platforming and it is really well done. it feels fluid and stratifying and though some segments can be quite challenging, it is downright euphoric once you manage to get it right. 

there are a few parts of the game i call "Chase sequences" for lack of a better term, where some hazard or similar obstacle  progresses along an area and you have to stay ahead of it. these sort of serve as this games equivalent to boss fights in terms of level design and are typically quite challenging albeit short and have no check points. that last bit was a matter of some frustration for me at first but once i completed the sequence i found the lack of checkpoint served to make the sequence extremely visually satisfying and gratifying enough that i didnt mind, not to mention the satisfaction of the actual feel of the platforming through the sequence once it all plays out perfectly. despite the comparative difficulty to the rest of the platforming, these are easily my favorite moments of the entire game.

now, this game does technically have combat but it is very minimal and simplistic. if you are coming into this looking for like, hollow knight or something thats not what you are going to get. as i mentioned earlier, there arent exactly boss fights that you conventionally fight and more often then not enemies feel more like a part of the platforming more than obstacles you have to fight

143310701.review:
Don't let the cute looking visuals fool you, this game is very hard and frustrating.
This is another example that proves that graphics aren't everything. Gameplay is what matters most.
The graphics look good, the story is light and interesting, the music is great, but the crushing difficulty broke everything for me. I tried to get through the game to see how the story ends, but the extremely difficult gameplay made me rage quit at every session.
The developers were really creative in making the enemies really annoying, designing insta-death traps everywhere, weird platforming mechanics and other shit. I give them that.

Controls are a big issue as well. The character always moves a bit further than you intend, the movement acceleration is weird (I can't find the correct words to describe this). You can easily get stun locked to death or get snapped to a death trap, which feels really cheap. I'm not new to this kind of games and not a newbie gamer. This game has serious issues with controlling movement, which is a crucial aspect of the game. I could swear I can make all jumps and platforming with much more ease if it was any other game of the same genre. I like a good challenge, not cheap artificial so-called difficulty.

Most of the skills you unlock feel useless. I'm already past half of the game, unlocked half of the skill tree points, and they only have very little to non-existing effect on the gameplay.

FYI The game doesn't have auto-save. You save manually anytime and almost anywhere as long as you have a power cell left. So save often.. if you still decided to play the game...

I didn't want to win a medal or get a world record, I just wanted a good game to enjoy and relax, and have a good time. This game clearly doesn't offer that. I would rather play Dark souls than this game. At least Dark souls is fair, Ori isn't.
I'm glad I didn't buy the second game (Ori and the will of the wisps). What a waste of time and money.. and what a disappointment.

This is one of those instances I wish I could give a neutral review. Overall the game is good but it has a very bizarre design choice. Why in the world would you give the player a total of 15 health points, damage reduction, and even difficulty options (???), and then design tons of instant-death hazards? Ori is obviously inspired by games like Metroid, and yet I don't remember *any* Metroid game with as many tedious deaths as this one. It also flies in the face of the pretty visuals and the traversal mechanics you unlock that give you freedom of movement; you're moving along swiftly enjoying the visuals, and then if you get hit by the wrong thing, instant death.

The stats say I have over 200 deaths and I believe it. Really hoping the sequel has better level-design.

143122998.review:
It certainly has its moments and some unique gameplay mechanics but late game puzzle platforming gimmicks with screwed up inverted controls, gravity, and other shenanigans are really more annoying than fun. The game also suffers from lack of ability to reload, so you have to basically constantly commit suicide if you take a hit because there is no point in going any further if you screw up early in long segments as enemies and spikes do so much damage. I probably spent half my time just wasting time killing myself on spikes on purpose. I used to hate instant death spikes but ori made me want them back because the time waste trying to kill myself was immense. The devs knew this too - there is a death counter. How many platformers have a death counter?

The game accidently let me save on spikes and softlocked. You can find many posts on steam forums you will see lots of posts of people with softlock situations. You have to quit to menu to find the hidden mechanic to load a previous save. It's not hinted to exist at all. 

Now the art style. It's nice, high def, muted pastel asthetic, but has a lot of visual clarity problems. Spikes and hazards blend in and often overlap with edges of what is normally walkable areas. The problem is even non-spiky parts of spikes will hurt you. How do sides of long shafts of spikes hurt you? Some of your and enemy projectiles look the same and are the same color, especially with spiders. You are both making big multishot flashes all over the screen and so you can't even see their projectiles. You have to stop shooting so you can even see them shoot back at you. 

There are also areas you can't ever get back to with upgrades that can be missed forever. Fun! Oh, I and hope you enjoy playing 5 minute long escape sequences from these forever gone places where you die in 1 hit and have to redo them over and over to find that couple pixel on the map where you can hide don't die. Die at the 4 minute mark, well start over before you can find those pixels. These are very controversial parts of the game and are love it or hate it for most people.

142983305.review:
This game looks really good, and sounds really nice too. I sound like a broken record. At least this one has a good narrative. It's simple, but the themes it presents, it presents them emotionally and without filler. It's prologue literally made me buy the game.

But I don't recomend this game, not at all. The level design is kind of all over the place. The distribution of challenges is well done. The problem is within those challenges, and the dynamics that ensue from the game's mechanics.

(played the default difficulty; don't know about easier or harder ones)

Basically, there are a lot of challenges that you have to know beforehand. There are some that are literally random. And some that are kind of random - skill mix, but let's just focus on the first ones, which are sufficiently abundant. The game gives you, surprisingly, a save button to save anywhere in exchange for resources, and it even has the kindness to let you recover health by doing so. This sounds great: auto-balancing challenge with resource management. It is all, however, a dirty lie, because the resource is so abundant that you can just save after every challenge, practically.

This makes the game a constant back and forth between saving, the devs laughing at your face for not knowing what was to come, then you avoiding the trap, and repeat. The game does have difficult sections, so it's not like it's all a breeze. My favorite ones, are, however, those in which they don't let you save, but still set a bunch of gotta-know traps so you have to reset from the start of the level sequence.

I can't say much about level design of secrets, because although I began taking notes of places I wanted to re-visit and clues for that, I dropped it when the game dropped the ball. Also, minor complain, why is it so frequent in this game to have foreground elements that look like background elements. Which kill you. Aa.

Besides all of that, it feels mechanically nice. Maybe a bit too much buttons to press, but that's just getting used to it. I don't like how Ori just accelerates like a motorjet, but again, that's just me. Also, the game pretends to have mini-bosses. They are not, they are a joke. And not even a funny one. Then again, with the level design matter, I wasn't going to recommend it anyway, at this point I'm just clowning.

142705610.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest is one I've been putting off for a while now. Very glad to have gotten around to it.

Pros:
- This game is absolutely stunning visually. Every environment feels distinct, and the vibrant color palette ties it all together to bring this intricate world to life; animations are also fantastic. The game manages to be melancholic, oppressive, adventurous, and lighthearted all in the same breath.
- You can't mention Ori without talking about the soundtrack. Each song is composed beautifully, accentuating key moments and making exploration all the more enjoyable.
- Ori himself controls phenomenally. Every movement feels fluid, and all of the many abilities you will unlock over the course of the game fit together to make some of the most satisfying movement from a platformer I've seen in quite a while (Bash is the greatest thing ever).
- Combat is basic but there is still a good amount of enemy variety that helps to keep things fresh.
- The narrative is executed very well for the most part, and delivers a simple yet touching story.
- Exploration is great, and each level was a joy to go through, especially the action-packed escape sequences following each of the three main 'dungeons'.
- Extra Definitive Edition content is also a welcome addition, providing yet another fun and well-crafted area to traverse.

Cons:
- For a metroidvania, Ori is almost completely linear. This is not a bad thing inherently, as each section of the game is masterfully crafted your first time through. However, side content/exploration/backtracking that followed the main story did not feel particularly inspired, and ended up being lots of locked doors that I simply needed late-game power-ups to access (Which I do not mind, but most of these were simply that and nothing more. I would have liked to see a bit more effort here - such as extra puzzles or combat encounters). It can't have been that bad though, because I still decided to 100% my save file.
- Soul Link is an interesting and unique mechanic, but I do still have somewhat mixed feelings about it.
- Despite the commendable enemy variety, the combat mechanics themselves are a bit lackluster, and fighting enemies did feel somewhat repetitive by the late-game.
- There are admittedly a couple story moments that I found a bit pointless, lowering the impact of other events considerably (will not be elaborating to avoid spoilers).


Ori and the Blind Forest is a triumph, and it's insane to think this was Moon Studios' first game. I am greatly looking forward to playing the sequel.

7.5/10

142691504.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest is a great platformer, but it might be lacking in replayability if that's something you like about metroidvania games.

The platforming itself feels great, with every new mechanic you get access to throughout the game lending itself very well to making movement feel fluid and seamless. Combat is a bit on the dull side, with very few differing enemy designs across the whole game, the player often getting to meet reskinned enemies with slightly different behavior and upgraded stats as they progress. As such, there are no bosses, with chase sections that test your platforming skills taking their place. This admittedly fits the game's strengths to a T.
Outside of gameplay, the game's visuals, sound design, OST and the storytelling complement each other perfectly to deliver a great atmosphere and make the forest of Nibel feel alive. Exploring the wilderness is made very intuitive thanks to how the in-game map functions, though it might make it a bit too easy if exploring is what you enjoy most out of a metroidvania.

Very fun, and I'll likely play it again! For sure recommend it.

142667438.review:
This game is beautiful. The animations, the backgrounds, the enemy designs, the cutscenes, it's all just breathtaking. The soundtrack and sound design is just as good, really fitting the tone of the situation and feeling like a movie. I'm afraid, though, that the gameplay doesn't live up to this game's presentation.

The platforming physics are incredible. Near the end of the game, after obtaining all of the abilities, platforming through the final section felt immensely satisfying. Being a long-time Mario fan, I love 2D platformers to death, so needless to say, those segments were my favorite part of this game. Of course, since I've already played so many 2D platformers, I've become quite good at them. This, I believe, is why I enjoyed this game so much. Which leads to my next point.

Here's the big platforming nitpick: This game can be hard. The wrong kind of hard, the frustrating kind. The way you save your game is quite unconventional, using entirely manual saves that take some of your magic energy to create. Imagine Celeste's respawn system, but instead of it triggering at the start of every room, saving is entirely done by the player, and can be created on any solid ground. Forgetting to save and needing to replay sections can be discouraging, and I ended up doing that throughout the entire game. even up to the final area I was forgetting to save at times. If you're out of magic energy, it can be very tough to make progress. And if you're in a section with very few energy pickups, you might just get stuck there for a while.

And now we talk about the combat, the weakest part of this game for most people. It's just as simple as people say it is. The whole thing is just spamming the X button, which is less than ideal, but I didn't mind it much. The enemies can be tough to dodge at times. I don't know what it is about them, but some enemies' attacks are so frustrating. Think of the Primal Aspids from Hollow Knight, but this time there's more like 3 or 4 enemy types in this game that are like them.

The Definitive Edition adds two abilities to the game which I have mixed feelings about. These abilities are the Dash and the Light Burst, and they make platforming a bit too easy. They are entirely optional pickups, but the strange thing is that the skill tree lets you unlock upgrades for these two powerups without ever picking them up in the first place. For example, I saw an upgrade on the skill tree with the description "Allows Ori to also dash in midair." (something like that) and when I spent my points on it, I was quite disappointed when I realized it was an upgrade to an ability I hadn't found yet. So please, if you end up playing this game, and you unlock or see something you don't understand, just look it up. This doesn't mean the Definitive Edition is the worse version though. It adds a fast travel system, which I used extensively during my playthrough, as well as more accessible difficulty options. So in the end the positives of the re-release outweigh my problems with the new abilities.

This is the longest Steam review I've ever written, but I've never played through a game where I had this much to say about it. This game isn't perfect, It's quite flawed actually. But I really, thoroughly enjoyed playing through it, and I hope whoever is reading this decides to try it out. If you're still indecisive, maybe wait for a sale and try it out then.

Everything in Ori and the Blind Forest is just solid. The chase sequences were definitely the best part of the game play with music and art style being a super tasty icing on the cake. Just a very good game that I think can be analysed in a more interesting manner compared to similar games and its sequel, Ori and the Willow of the Wisps. 
Ori and the Willow of the Wisps discussion is more suited for its on review but I'll comment that the sequel 100% improves in every aspect from the first game. 
A lot of reviews mention the comparison between Hollow knight and both Ori games, but I think the comparison does not apply nearly as much to the first game. Apart from being in the same genre (metroidvania 2D platformer) Ori and the Blind Forest and Hollow Knight have very little in common. Mainly because the first Ori game focuses on platforming, escape sequences and puzzle solving rather than fighting or exploration. The game is essentially linear compared to Hollow Knight's multitude of ways you can traverse the map. If you're looking to get Ori and the Blind Forest, it won't be like Hollow Knight.

Very good game 8/10.

142539762.review:
Alright. **Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition** is NOT done and dusted.

It's an unquestionably beautiful game with stunning artwork and exceptional detail. You could truly get lost in the visuals which might be some of the best in any video game ever. It's truly that breathtaking and evocative.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3007766422

The audio is similarly well done. Not quite to the peerless excellence of the artwork, but the OST is ethereal and pretty, and the in game tracks all are perfect for what they are.

The platforming and combat are extremely tight and the controls are as responsive as I've seen in such a game. Also, the upgrade system gives you a very real sense of progression, allowing you to access new parts of areas you've already visited, and just to enjoy a steady flow of new abilities.

The story, so far as I got into it, was pretty dark and sad. The intro can really make you feel pretty bad, and as you progress, you realize that while the game steers you in a hopeful direction, the path is littered with heartache.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3007766385

So, this all sounds like a winning combination of aspects that come together into a brilliant gaming experience, and that is actually factual. What I realized however, is that I don't have the patience for the increasingly complex puzzles, which require very precise platforming, multiple reflex based phases, and aiming that I can do, but not without getting pissed off lol. The actual solutions are pretty obvious, but the actual act of accomplishing them is more than I am personally willing to put myself through.

So...I definitely recommend this game if you are patient and don't mind repeating the same thing over and over trying to get it just right, rinse and repeat. If instead, you are at all impatient or prone to rage quitting games, this is a game better YouTubed instead.

[code]If you found this review helpful and would be interested in supporting my Curator group, it would be appreciated. Cheers.
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32549618/[/code]

First metroidvania and I love this style of play. In a really cool overhaul, having a skill tree is really good and but also not mandatory to advance the story but gives a big boost, little stupid bugs on the other hand (like stuck in a corner under infinite jump animation, puzzles that weren't validating or that had to be updated by death), Cool DA chill and quiet music. 

The progression of the game is really intuitive, when you get a new skill, the difficulty and the learning curve is really easy, and a neophyte of metroidvania and even video games in general can understand and come up with difficult passages quite easily.
The level design is well thought out, and when you think you can't access parts, you just have to watch carefully.

[b] Positives part [/b] : Really dynamic gameplay, can progress at own rhythm, nice DA and musics. Easy to learn and to master, et hard to master if you want to be tricky. Replayable.
[b] Negatives part [/b]: Got too much bugs for the achievements, could finish the game more early.

[b] Warning [/b] (for those who wants to 100% the game or for those who wants to get some achievements) :

- For the achievements who need to kills ennemies with some specifics attacks, there is a chance to not get the achievement if you have died in the session before, so for this restart the game and steam, it should work
- For the One Death achievement, if you have died and you have restarted directly through the game, instead destroy your save and start over in another one.
- If you play a big game, to discover the game, be careful with the "difficult mode", do not try to have all the skills, it requires 1.5 x more points or even twice as many to obtain them all.

Beside that, it was really good. Go play it !

141885949.review:
As someone who played both Ori games back to back, I will say that I do like Will of the Wisps a lot more. That isn't to say this is a bad much less weak game, it's still a great metroidvania worth your time! The way the world begins to open as you go somewhere new, gain a new ability, have a tutorial built into the environment as you climb/explore outwards, and then backtrack through once unreachable paths is handled to a masterful degree. As well as most mechanics overall working for what the game wanted to accomplish.

I will say, some sections can easily feel uncomfortable to play, and they can easily overstay their welcome due to issues I find in the movement system and pacing, I find that the ice temple (I forget the name of it, sorry!) is generally poorly communicated as well as designed, the puzzle mechanic is hard to pick up on because it never gives you a space to tinker with the gravity mechanic used there, as well as the chase section being unreasonably difficult and poorly communicated to the player in most aspects, this made it hard to trust that I would enjoy following chase sections, and sadly, I think the final chase before the credits is also pretty bad in communicating to the player. Adding on to that with the end-game area being a massive spike in difficulty from the rest of the game, it can get frustrating to play with generally poor pacing of difficulty and easily frustrating execution of mechanics. However! I find that majority of the game is a genuine pleasure to go through and experience, the rough edges do not ruin the whole package for me, as there's lots of great aspects here! (This is also where I mention I think that Will of the Wisps executes basically everything here I had problems with to an extremely phenomenal level of game design and you should totally play that game too)

141674963.review:
Ori is a metroidvania title that not many people talk about now days in lieu of Hollow Knight but the two titles were big influences on one another and at the time they came out were both raising the bar for the genre. 

First and foremost the Ori games look and sound beautiful, the artwork and animation are impressive with special attention being paid to lighting and particles that give the game's ethereal world so much atmosphere only added to by the orchestral world-music score. The game looks like a high quality animated feature every step of the way. The gameplay is all about mobility. The world is built to be a playground that you slide, twirl, jump, and bound through making Ori feel like they're truly at home in the forest through control alone. 

Every motion naturally flows into another and the world design encourages you to make use of every option, with the later movement unlocks only making every journey even more swift and natural to counterbalance the world map's constant expansion. Combat is simple and revolves around button mashing to bypass foes but this game isn't about fighting its the puzzle platforming. Using the high quality movement mechanics to navigate spatial challenges in beautiful spaces collecting items to continue forward. 

Each area has an elemental gimmick that is used to provide new movement challenges keeping things fresh throughout. It goes to show that creativity doesn't require crazy new ideas, even basic platforming and old level themes can be executed well to provide a rewarding gameplay experience. This game even foregoes boss fights, instead presenting big cinematic platforming sections that challenge you to get from A to B using all the tricks you've learned in the previous area. It's actually really clever to see Ori playing constantly into its biggest strength.

The story is minimal but revolves around the cycles of life and death in the large ethereal forest setting. Just as the gameplay focuses on doing one thing well, so too does the story focus on singular strong themes that resonate throughout the entire game and left me tearing up on several occasions.

Overall Ori is a solid metroidvania and while it doesn't have flashy tools or hardcore combat its game design goes to show the strength of minimalism and remains a masterclass in moving through 2D spaces.

141657593.review:
This game is not good. If I had to summarize it in a sentence, I'd say it feels like an unusually ambitious game development project for college that expectedly falls short of actual "game" quality.
I spent a good amount of time on this game when I was younger (10, 11, 12 maybe) and tried to pick it up again to finish it which I had never done before. I did this because one of my most trusted game reviewers said it was one of his favorites of all time and because it was on sale for cheap. I still refunded it because it didn't feel worth keeping.

What are the issues? From what I either experienced or looked up on YouTube after refunding it, this is what I can gather:
- The environments are ugly and dark. No, this is not a setting on my computer. Everything feels so abysmal, even the lighter and cheerier areas. Never once did I see something and go "Wow! That looks visually impressive, or even visually tolerable!" 
-The story can literally be explained in thirty seconds or less. There are no captivating details or lore or intricacies to the world that make it worth mentioning. When I say within thirty seconds, if you're a fast enough talker, you can probably explain every lore-related game mechanic in an additional twenty.
-The save system is so lame. I don't want to have to see the same cutscene over and over again because I don't have energy or just forgot to save. Either they should have done autosave or they should have just done a more integrated and widespread checkpoint system of sorts, making ability upgrades a mobile endeavor.
-The mechanics are truly awful. What kind of combat is there? You click a button and it hurts enemies. No aiming or anything rewarding associated with it. You can also hold down a button if you feel saucy. The platforming is punishing, but not really punishing for the sake of difficulty, more like punishing because the jumps aren't outlined well enough to land consistently. The jumping, climbing and other mechanics didn't feel polished at all.
In summary of that section of the review, traversal, managing saves and combat were just chores on the way through a semblance of a story that literally could have been cranked out in twenty minutes in a conference room.

What does this game have to offer? It's not intellectually challenging or emotionally moving enough to grab my attention, but the "spiritual" adventure that it pushes is almost equally underwhelming when the world feels so uninspired almost all of the time. I might just be a hardass but this game is an incredible letdown. I'm going to buy the next one at some point to see if it improves upon the formula, but if it doesn't then I really have nothing good to say about this series. I'm pretty upset.

141548316.review:
First off, let me preface by saying that this is one of those games that make me wish for a "mixed rating" option. It's not bad, I just personally think there are better alternatives for pretty much everything it has to offer, and my experience didn't come close to the hype surrounding it. The art is outstanding, but as a metroidvania, it feels to me like it falls short on every single aspect compared to its peers – which is apparently a sentiment [i]not[/i] shared by many people. I'll go into detail below, spoilers will be marked.

The exploration is not very interesting or rewarding – the game tells you exactly where you need to go, and due to its extreme linearity, you get absolutely nothing from going off the beaten path; in terms of secrets, most of what you get is XP that you'll have probably maxed out by the time you get to the last dungeon regardless of how much you've actually explored, the rest is health/mana upgrades that become basically useless down the line due to unlocking skills that drastically reduce damage received and mana costs. The only case where I can see these secrets being actually meaningful is in hard more, but it's pretty clear that this difficulty setting was not intended for a first playthrough due to the fact that almost everything one-shots you in the early game, aka the part where you're supposed to play around the most to figure out the "rules" of the game.

Combat gets stale real quick; bash is a very cool power – if you play on controller, that is – but it completely erases the need to dodge enemy attacks, so encounters become a matter of mashing the (auto-aim) attack button as quickly as possible while holding the bash button as soon as you see something move. It could've turned out interesting nonetheless if the devs had gotten more creative with enemy designs, but alas, only two of them have gimmicks that actually require you to approach them differently; for everyone else, spamming attacks and bashes is more than enough. The other powers are basically useless in combat, aside from the insanely powerful ground stomp whose AoE is so humongous that you're more likely to hit enemies by accident than miss them.

Platforming is nice, arguably the best part of the game, but it's not as good as dedicated platformers, and I personally don't think there's anything that makes up for the difference. Besides, I feel like some sections are somewhat poorly balanced, with hazards either dealing so little damage that you can just walk on them without issue or instantly killing you for a single mistake – in which case, you'd better have set up a save point not too long ago, or you'll have to make your whole way there all over again. Admittedly, the sheer speed you can traverse the map with in the late game is quite satisfying, but it feels like the game actively tries to slow you down at times, making it feel kinda pointless.

Finally, the story. It starts off great, and you get the sense that things aren't quite the way they seem from the beginning. But in the end, it left me really confused about its message. Like okay, [i]"don't let hatred consume you or you'll lose the things you care about the most",[/i] but how can you look me straight in the eye and tell me that [spoiler]Kuro is the bad guy for desperately trying to protect her only remaining child from the god that murdered her entire family along with Ori's adoptive mother just because he lost track of Ori, and [i]HE's the good guy???[/i] The one you serve throughout the entire game with no second thoughts? It doesn't make any sense to me. I was expecting a nuanced take on the balance between light and darkness, something about neither of the two things being inherently good or evil, and as such, neither deserving to be overwhelmed by the other. What I got instead was a banal [i]"light is good, and if darkness has to be suppressed for its sake, then so be it. What's that? Innocents dying because of this? It is what it is, man."[/i][/spoiler]

That's about it. As I said in the beginning, I don't think the game is terrible, but I just don't see any reason to recommend it over pretty much any other metroidvania I've played, unless you're a fan of platformers trying to get into the genre and you're put off by "traditional" combat, or conversely, you've exhausted all other options and are itching for yet more metroidvania (which was more or less my case, but in hindsight, I should've picked something else).

141424181.review:
This game is actually misery to play. Other than the art style and music, I have nothing good to say about this game. Game play is awful, power progression is awful, clarity is awful, exploration is awful and story is awful.

To start off, the combat is almost non-existent in this game, it consists of button mashing a single button to kill enemies while standing completely still and once you are 30% through the game there is really no reason to ever kill enemies again. the damage done to enemies is so small its a complete chore to sit there for 15 second to kill a single standard enemy. Once you get the ability to launch off enemies, I think I maybe killed 10 enemies the rest of the game. You do not scale with the enemies and the abilities you obtain through the skill tree are all but useless.

Movement in this game is not smooth in the slightest, it is way to floaty and non consistent. CLimbing up walls is a headache, trying to land precisely on a platform is a gamble and waiting for a specific enemy to line up perfectly for a platforming section is a casino slot machine.

When traversing the world, it is near impossible to see what is going to kill you. Are those just boring bushes or are those spikes? It is so unclear when something will damage you it is hilarious. This game greatly sacrifices any clarity for the sake of art direction. The least enjoyable parts of the game were the "escape" portions in each of the area. These were not a test of skill, but a continuous beating your head against a metaphorical wall until you finally escape. You are running along and a rock falls on your head with no visual clue, time to restart the entire sequence until I get surprised again by some BS. The only way to know is through trial and error, so you end up being forced to do this portion a ton of times until you know all the gimmicks that will be thrown your way. A skilled individual should be able to do these in just a few tries not be forced to die at every step of the way because of lack of clarity.

Exploration is almost non existent in this game unless you are trying to 100% the game. Extra health doesn't matter, extra soul doesn't matter, getting new skills in the skill tree do not matter. Unless you want to explore to see a hole in ground and get a shiny orb to get more useless stuff, exploration is worthless. There are no cool ares or power ups that you get from going out of your way to explore the world. Also there are so many points in the game where you can't go back and get something you missed so if you are trying to get everything and miss it once, you're fucked.

(spoilers) And for a game that is known for its "great story" I was appalled at what was going on. The purpose is for you to restore the forest and save this magic tree while trying to escape the wrath of an owl. Turns out the tree absolutely murders the the owl babies and now we are still supposed to save the tree?? Fuck that I'm teaming up with the owl and burning this place down. I'm not trying to save a baby owl murderer. And at the end the only way for the owl to save his last baby is to get himself killed by the tree. That is so fucked. I hope in the sequel I get to burn the tree down.

141321445.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest is a beautifully aesthetic yet challenging platformer which progresses fairly typically of metroid style platformers. While the challenge is very clearly present, it doesn't make world progression overly cryptic which is quite nice - most of the challenge comes in navigating hostile environments, which  can get a little annoying at times. To give an example, some environmental spikes have extremely deceptive collision detection, and there are certain parts of the game involving extreme timing and perfection and may require several restarts. There were a few areas that felt like some of the harder levels in Super Meat Boy (very challenging). That said, if you play the game right, you won't be backtracking too much, which is a particular peeve of mine typically present within this genre. Acquired abilities are useful outside of their progressionary intent, which is also refreshing.

I can't however mention enough how beautiful this game is. The art style is lush and vibrant; terrain and backdrops look almost as though they have been painted, creating a truly joyful atmosphere. The soundtrack is also pretty solid and only adds to the games charm. There is a story present, albeit a basic one, but this certainly doesn't detract from the general gameplay, and some feels were had in certain parts of the game. I thoroughly enjoyed this game and will look forward to playing the sequel! The most important advice I can give regarding this game, is to not be fooled by the Ghibli-esque visuals. This is a TOUGH game, harder than Hollow Knight and instead more comparable to the Path of Pain sections at certain points.

[b]Pros:[/b]
Beautiful game design.
Intuitive and responsive controls.
Well thought out level design with regards to backtracking.

[b]Cons:[/b]
Sometimes unfair collision detection.
Brutal platforming challenges at times.
Changes of pacing that can give you a false sense of security.
Enemy variations are a bit lacking.

141161124.review:
This game is a masterpiece, strongly recommend for those who want challenging gameplay and good graphics.
The soundtrack is incredible and fits in so well with the different parts of the storyline. The controls and mechanics are introduced at a pace that keeps the game interesting, while also giving you time to learn them so you don't get overwhelmed with all the moves and abilities that can be used. I have completed the main story on normal mode, and the gameplay is challenging (and sometimes a bit rage-inducing) but it stays interesting by giving you a vast range of unique areas to explore, and puzzles to solve. The main character, Ori, is animated so well and when using all the different abilities, the animation is smooth. While there are no 'bosses' in this game, this is greatly redeemed by having [spoiler]various fast paced escape sequences where you utilise what you have learnt in a challenging race against dangers that are so beautiful and they make you feel so good once you complete them :)[/spoiler]
My only criticisms are that the manual saving is a bit awkward and a lot of the enemies are just re-skins of previous ones, with slightly different abilities.  

However i have a few tips for those who are new:
- You will die a lot, Don't let the graphics fool you, this game is difficult. If you wanted a relaxing game, this is not what you are looking for
- Save your game a lot. The game doesn't autosave very often and if you die you will go back to your last save so do this to avoid losing your progress.
- Early game spoilers: [spoiler] Collect as many life/energy cells as you can earlier on so that you will find late game a lot easier. Often in late game you wont be able to save due to a lack of energy so more energy points helps with this :)[/spoiler]
