Ori is a Metroidvania style platformer. It is a gorgeous game, and has some really great level design. I especially loved the escape sequences for their added tension, and the feeling of flow that they create. I do have one complaint that took away a decent bit from my experience, though.

I typically enjoy the hard difficulty on most games. But on Ori, I would recommend avoiding this. The combat in this game is a bit of an afterthought, and hard mode REALLY demonstrates this. Mashing one single button while an orb does all the work for you is NOT fun, especially when hard mode just nerfs your health and damage making these sections last even longer. Pop it in on normal or even easy to hide these issues and you're in for a fun time.

This game deserves praise for its good ideas (the bash move is especially genius), but even more for its presentation. The visuals and soundtrack are both stunning. Combined with the story, this feels like playing through an A-tier Pixar movie. Also, without this game, Ori and the Will of the Wisps wouldn't exist-- and that game is an absolute masterpiece. 

7.5/10

141071466.review:
Is it pretty? Yes. Is it fun to play? Absolutely not.

Floaty controls, auto-grabbing/hopping of ledges, an art style that makes background hard to distinguish from foreground, unintuitive hazards and mechanics, a completely uninteresting combat system that involves spamming a single button which auto targets enemies which is 100% invalidated and made pointless by bash, a single path upgrade system, pickups that don't matter, special moves able to be bought before they are able to be used, all enemies that exist solely as a means to attack you and interrupt platforming, boss fights that are beyond meh, forced cutscenes which cannot be skipped that replay every time you respawn unless you save afterwards, and a map that is the same in every area except with different background textures ... this game is the most overrated thing I have ever come across.

It is very clear the game designers were artists and not gamers. There is nothing fun about this game. There is no real incentive to exploring, no gratification in the platforming, endless frustration with the game taking control out of your hands, the areas are uninteresting, the levels are designed in ways that are annoying and not fun, mechanics are applied inconsistently, there's hardly any variety of enemies, the screen moves too slowly and can't keep up with your character which is too zoomed out to see clearly with all the foreground/background objects being intermixed ... it is literally almost every single aspect of the game that is the problem.

The only thing this game has is that it is pretty to look at for the first 10 minutes. Then it is just a colorful blob you can't tell what's happening and you walk into tiny spikes or hot objects you couldn't tell were spiky or hot and die instantly.

140914623.review:
Now listen, this game is objectively great, I just did not enjoy it as much as I'd hoped.

There is nothing inherently wrong with the game, and it's also extremely polished. Movement feels AMAZING, and the visuals are stunning, but these seems to sadly be the only great things about Ori. This game is a metroidvania, which means that exploration is given an enormous priority, and that felt great as well... at first. But the game is one fundamental flaw: the skill tree. I cannot state how easily this game could have turned out better, if only the skill tree was given less of a priority. 

For example, as I said ,exploring should be at the forefront of this game. And yet, one of the very first upgrades you get is a tracker, which tells you exactly where every collectible is found on the map, INCLUDING PLACES YOU HAVEN'T VISITED YET. So, very early in the game, you're basically shown the entirety of the map through these collectible locations, and you're no longer incentivised to explore as much as you should, since your experience with the game turns into a simple matter of opening the map, checking where the next closest collectible is, go there directly, and repeat. Exploration is no longer relevant, because you're constantly given a direction to move towards. And this is only one of the problems with this skill tree, although I feel like I've rambled enough about it already.

The thing is... tuning slightly these systems would have improved the user experience tremendously, and it's such a shame that such a polished game was built around such weak mechanics (except for the movement, that's still awesome).

Sorry... I would not recommend playing this game... but you do you, hopefully I'm just wrong and you'll enjoy it :)

140886198.review: This game rated 10/10 for style and 4/10 for substance. The presentation-- from the music and sound design to art and animation-- is incredible, and from a surface-level perspective makes Ori and the Blind Forest a strong contender for Games As Art. The visual aspects in particular were probably groundbreaking when it released, and show no signs of aging or being obsoleted. But the story and gameplay are lacking depth. The story relies on cheap tear-jerker plot elements to get the player emotionally invested, and doesn't have much to say beyond "family is good" and "be nice to people." The gameplay vacillates between simplistic but workable sections and frustratingly precise scripted sequences. Overall I don't regret playing the game, but I'm still walking away hoping that the sequel provides better mechanical elements to complement the superb stylistic elements.

140802772.review:
The atmosphere is amazing, but I wish the awful game design didn't try its very best to pull me out of it during the first two hours of me playing it.

For a platformer, the motion feels too floaty and uncontrolled for the environment. It might be better with a controller than with a keyboard, but a [i]remastered[/i] version of a game should just get this right. But that's only where it starts; it's often very hard to estimate, from looking at the environment and having had some exercise with your motion, whether you should or shouldn't be able to make the jump with your current abilities. If you're making a Metroidvania platformer, this should be a disqualifying quality.

Not only is it hard to estimate whether you can make that jump, but also whether the enemy that's barely even on screen can jump on top of you. This makes you want to run away at the first sight of any enemy that you haven't seen before (or sometimes even that you think you've seen before, but this shapeless blob looks slightly different and has wildly different attacks), and get ready to spam your attack when it gets near, because enemies take a ton of hits before you're done with them. And this is "normal" difficulty.

But what prompted me to uninstall the game, where the two times that the game design, in the sense how the game signals to you how to progress towards a goal, wasted my time.

In [spoiler]the first half of Black Root Burrows[/spoiler], the game will teach you a new mechanic by sending you through a whole obstacle course. After you're done with it, you're in a nearly empty room ([spoiler]the jumping puzzle immediately before you dispel the darkness in Black Root Burrows[/spoiler]). This is usually a game's way to tell you that [u]you don't really have to learn any new tricks, you just have to apply them[/u]. And that will leave you stuck, until you figure out that you can also drop the object you're holding, which is not something you were taught (through necessity, or hints, or by accident) during the obstacle course. What's worse, once you drop the object, all your dynamics have changed, so you'll jump over [spoiler]the ghost platform next to you[/spoiler] the first time around. You're going to need a few attempts, which each take a frustrating half a minute of retrieving the object and using it to get back up again. There's a reason that failures result in fast retries in games in this genre, but this game missed that memo.

I only did that puzzle because I was stuck on another puzzle. I had pushed a rock into what clearly was a "slot" near [spoiler]the well near Thornfelt Swamp[/spoiler]. If an object "slots" into something, then that's usually a game's way to tell you [u]it is in the right place and you don't have to touch it anymore[/u]. At that point, I could wall jump, so I tried jumping up from this rock onto a wall next to it, but I only grazed the corner of that wall each time. I didn't have the double jump ability that the ability tree hinted on, so I figured I needed to get that first. After scouting the entire map for something I might have missed, and getting stuck in the aforementioned part of [spoiler]Black Root Burrows[/spoiler], I returned to the rock. As it turns out, you can't push or pull the rock out of the slot, but your attempts to do so ever so slightly rotate the rock, giving you just enough pixels of extra jump height to jump up that wall.

[i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] really has nothing on [i]Hollow Knight[/i] (Metroidvania platformer) and [i]Celeste[/i] (not a Metroidvania, but a focus on skillful platforming). Those games at least left me with the feeling that I should've known better and could've done better each time I died or failed a jump.

140487009.review:
[b] INTRO. [/b]
Bought the game to relax from my examination week. However, to my surprise, the game turned out to be an exceptional experience, surpassing my expectations of it, so I decided to create a review. Ori and the Blind Forest effortlessly blends stunning visuals, enchanting storytelling, and tight gameplay mechanics to create an unforgettable gaming experience(mainly due to dying), like literally I can't recount how much I died from this game, which made me more stressful which is a good thing right?..

[b] Story [/b]
The game introduces players to Ori, a small guardian spirit tasked with restoring the forest's balance after a catastrophic event. Through the course of the game, Ori's journey becomes a metaphor for self-discovery, friendship, and sacrifice. The storytelling is done primarily through visual and atmospheric cues, with minimal dialogue, yet it manages to tug at the heartstrings and elicit genuine emotions from me.

[b] SOUND DESIGN [/b]
The game's sound design and music deserve special mention. The orchestral score composed by Gareth Coker perfectly complements the game's visuals and emotional beats The melodies are hauntingly beautiful, capturing the essence of each moment. Combined with the atmospheric sound effects, the audio immerses players in the world of Ori and adds an extra layer of immersion. 

[b] VISUAL [/b]
One of the most striking features of Ori and the Blind Forest is its breathtaking visual design. The colors are rich and varied, seamlessly transitioning between serene and tranquil moments to intense and action-packed sequences. The visual beauty of the game is further enhanced by the fluid animations. In short this game is good in sense of atmosphere, visuals, sound design.

[b] GAMEPLAY [/b]
Beyond its aesthetics and narrative, Ori and the Blind Forest boasts polished gameplay mechanics that are both challenging and rewarding. The platforming elements are finely tuned, demanding precise timing and nimble reflexes. Although I recommend this game [b] I WOULD NOT [/b] recommend it to people who are looking to play [b] tension-free gameplay[/b]. While Ori and the Blind Forest offers an incredible gaming experience, it's important to note that the gameplay can occasionally be intense and challenging, leading to moments of frustration. It's like a relationship with a mischievous spirit that tests your patience, and occasionally makes you question your life choices, but you can't help but keep coming back for more for the sake of completion. ㅜㅜ

[b] CONCLUSION [/b]
Ori and the Blind Forest is an extraordinary game that excels in the visuals, storytelling and.. gameplay(if you like intense challenges I guess). Would I play it again? YES AND NO, I have a love-hate relationship with this game so I can't really decide.

Out of the topic but you can check out my guide for 100% completion, hope it helps!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2992488344

Have a good day^^

140300485.review:
[h1] Ori and the Blind Forest REVIEW: [/h1] 

[b] Ori and the Blind Forest [/b] is a [u] platform-adventure Metroidvania video game [/u] developed by [b] Moon Studios [/b] and published by [b] Microsoft Studios [/b]. The game was released for Windows and Xbox One in March 2015, and for Nintendo Switch in September 2019. Players assume control of [u] Ori [/u], a small white spirit, and Sein, the "light and eyes" of the Forest's Spirit Tree. Players are tasked to move between platforms and solve puzzles.

Let me start off with saying how [u] BEAUTIFUL LOOKING [/u] this game is ( and [b] Will of the Wisps [/b] gets better ). From the first 10 minutes into this game you already are amazed by the beauty this game throws into your eyes alongside tears because of what happens and how they set up the game of telling a story of [b] friendship, selflessness, and loss [/b]. This game indeed made me shed a few tears at a few moments of the game. The [u] Soundtrack[/u] of this game is also super chill and amazing to listen to be it in-game or outside of it. The [u] Gameplay [/u] is pretty straightforward and expected from a platform-adventure Metroidvania game but there is something about the movement that is in this game that is super easy but hard to master. As you play through the game you learn new [u] skills for combat and movement [/u] to use like powerful jump, hanging on walls or slamming into the ground with force BUT with new skills comes new challenges to master, an example is that Ori can fire energy orbs at nearby foes when he isn't avoiding them completely, and those creatures can be difficult to overcome. The blobs that stick to walls and ceilings? They aren't much of a hassle, at least until they coat the surfaces you need to cross and spit acid onto the ground. This game is in no shape easy even on easy difficulty, you need to learn from your mistakes and failure and master every move to be able to move into next area. Not gonna lie i actually did almost rage quit the game or shouted few bad words when i was playing on the hard difficulty but it was not that i was frustrated or game’s fault but instead it was just me failing on a part cause i either miss-timed it or rushed and the custom save system where you can use one energy point to save whenever you feel like to was the best choice developers did for this game 👏. The best part of this game has to be the [spoiler] the escape sequences few rooms have to offer as you restore light to this lost forest. They are intense and pulse-pounding BUT it makes you appreciate the game's visual artistry.  Multiple layers give each environment a lovely sense of depth [/spoiler]

[b] Overall to summarize. Ori and the Blind Forest is a beautiful, heart-touching and very clever game from Moon Studios and its story, soundtrack, world, graphics and art style is beautiful from start to end. Gameplay is also super fun to play and level design always keep you on thinking to be fast and responsive. I HIGHLY Recommend this game for its price point and looking forward to playing Will of the Wisps next [/b]

140225648.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest es una historia hecha videojuego. Esto puede sonar a que está mal adaptado a este medio. Nada más lejos de la realidad. Ori and the Blind Forest es un videojuego increíble. Aunque sí que se nota algún punto flojo.

Jugablemente, es genial. Tiene unos controles súper fluidos que a manos de expertos, son una delicia de ver solamente. Esto si lo combinamos con la cantidad ingente de habilidades que se consiguen tanto obligatoriamente como las que se obtienen en el árbol de habilidades, crea un set de movimientos muy amplio en el que puedes hacer auténticas virguerías. 

Con el mapa tengo sentimientos encontrados. Por una parte, me ha gustado, tiene entornos variados, un diseño bastante parecido al de un metroidvania (por su "no linealidad"), muchas secciones plataformeras que aprovechan a la perfección el control tan bueno que tenemos sobre Ori, pero por otra parte, me ha parecido muy lineal para ser un metroidvania. Va llevándote de la mano indicándote dónde está todo y a dónde tienes que ir. Pero en general, es un muy buen mapa.

Audiovisualmente, es hermoso. Pocos juegos he visto con un soundtrack que pueden hacerte llorar o animarte al mismo tiempo. Tiene un montón de temas súper épicos que llegan al corazón y quiero dar mi enhorabuena a la orquesta dedicada al OST del juego. Y visualmente es una delicia. Es un juego precioso, con un montón de colores, con diseños de personajes y lugares espectaculares... Podría pasarme horas diciendo lo bueno que es en este aspecto.

Y la historia es muy buena. Lo que menciono al principio de la reseña de "una historia hecha videojuego" se nota. Se centra mucho en temas como el amor padre-hijo, el sacrificio y la lealtad, creando una trama con momentos muy trágicos que pueden hacer llorar.

En conclusión, Ori and the Blind Forest es un juegazo que por su duración (unas 7,5 horas en mi caso) se te puede hacer mi caro, pero créeme que merece completamente la pena. Recomendadísimo.

140157649.review:
Sadistically difficult.

Admittedly, I got lured in by the beautiful graphics and 'Overwhelmingly Positive' review score. What an amazing beginning. Emotional, beautiful, heartfelt. 90 minutes in I was screaming obscenities and white-knuckling my controller.

The nanosecond timing and pixel-perfect jumping required totally ruined the experience for me. Like, it was just brutal. Apparently I'm in the minority here, but I feel like the thematic elements and the difficulty don't compliment each other.

I didn't expect walking simulator-type difficulty, but I also wasn't prepared for how absolutely enraging the experience would be.

140142241.review:
this game captivated me from start to finish. i picked it up hearing nothing but good praises about it, and it turns out, its true. the gameplay is a perfect blend of platforming and exploration, offering both challenging obstacles and rewarding discoveries.

the story is beautifully crafted, evoking a range of emotions with little to no voice lines and very few expositions from a third-person perspective, akin to storytelling in a book. the characters and their relationships are endearing. i found myself genuinely invested in their fates, which made the game all the more immersive.

one aspect that truly impressed me is the game's attention to detail. every pixel feels meticulously placed, and the level design is a work of art. the controls are smooth and responsive, allowing for precise platforming and satisfying combat encounters. backtracking to older maps once you unlock higher-tier skills also felt very rewarding, always offering new exploration experiences.

above all, Ori and the Blind Forest Definitive Edition is a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming.
it effortlessly combines breathtaking visuals, a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, and a touching narrative to create an unforgettable experience. the only unfortunate thing for me is that this game is relatively short, but there are ways to challenge yourself if you're looking for more playtime.

Game has great visual and audio design, undoubtedly, but here are the things that I didn't like:

139901667.review:
Writing this review fresh off of finally beating the game, I can say it was a rollercoaster ride.

OatBF is a musical and artistic masterpiece, telling a simple but fairly interesting story full of emotion and magic. There is a lot to like here, including many good gameplay ideas that should work in theory.
However, the experience is unfortunately soured by some frustrating level design, repetitive combat, and sometimes overly complex/clunky controls which WILL cause unnecessary deaths. The manual save system also caused a lot of frustration for me.
You will find out quickly that this is a DIFFICULT GAME, even on normal difficulty, and I was very close to changing to easy a few times just so I wouldn't have to rerun whole sections for the 6th time (e.g. chase sequences which do contain checkpoints on easy), but I only gave in to 1 section.
I was mainly playing this for the story, and given I'm not an avid metroidvania player, had I known how frustrating it was going to be, I might not have bought it.

However, after taking some time to collect my thoughts, I am glad I got to experience it, and while I personally won't be playing it again or buying the sequel, for anyone who enjoys this style of game, there's plenty here to satisfy your tastebuds, and the experience alone is worth the discounted price.

139840160.review:
I like this game a lot. The environments and music are both absolutely stunning. I can't overstate how good this game looks and sounds. Just beautiful. The story also pulled at my heart strings and had me in tears a couple of times.

As for the gameplay, you may have heard that the combat is bad but that only apply's to the basic attack. The "Bash" move you get early on is incredibly fun. It lets you catapult yourself off enemies and projectiles and even redirect projectiles into other enemies. Just use that as much as you can.

The platforming is where you'll really be tested anyway. The dungeons and boss fights are all platforming gauntlets. There's an occasional puzzle, but this game is a lot more Super Meat Boy than you might guess. Meat Boy isn't really my cup of tea, but the art, music and the bash move really carry it for me.

139814742.review:
A fun Metroidvania-style platformer with lots of cool abilities and extremely beautiful and vibrant visuals. The game was challenging, sometimes frustrating, but overall a decent balance if you're willing to tough it out. I liked the puzzle sections but I won't lie about some of the solutions being unclear. I had to cheese some of the platformer puzzles to progress in the game lol. 

Now let's get down to my skill issues: I had a hard time 100% my save file due to an area that I missed which the map didn't indicate. I guess maybe that can be due to user error but it was literally a small section in the Ginso Tree that I visited but didn't step on. I literally went up and down the whole tree a good half a dozen times and let me tell you, I was about to cry lmao

With that being said, I didn't have as good of a time that I hoped I would with this game. Maybe it's because of the game's reputation and I expected a lot more from it. That's definitely a me problem though. There's various gimmicks throughout the game, especially in the major sections, most involving puzzles and platforming. I enjoyed a lot of them and when I figured out the solution to some of these section I was like "Ohhh, I get it now. That's really that's cool." 

I also liked the save anywhere mechanic but I do realize it could be a problem for some. You have to be strategic as it uses your energy but if you're like me then you did lots of the collectibles and abilities to mitigate this problem. Although, I can totally see this being extremely frustrating for younger players. 

I liked this game overall. The story was predictable and a little too saccharine for my tastes. It's the visuals and gameplay which I would say are mostly really good. The music was also good but some of the sections where the music is supposed to be emotional didn't really hit for me.

Once you get the full arsenal of movement the game becomes a lot more fun and almost trivial once you get the hang of things. I did have lots of fun zipping around and using enemies as bounce pads. The game rewards exploration and searching every nook and cranny to find something that can make Ori a much more fun character to play as.

I'd say the hardest parts about this game for me was honestly the sections with the owl, especially the last one. I was getting so mad after dying over and over that when the ending of the game occurred I didn't really care. I wish I felt some type of happiness or satisfaction with the ending but I didn't. Again, a lot of my problems boil down to skill issues and minor gripes with gimmicks, puzzles, and difficulty in some parts. 

I definitely would recommend this game if you're into platformers and/or metroidvanias. It's challenging and it has lots to offer in it's core gameplay loop. Would I play this again? Maybe but I don't plan on doing so anytime soon. If you're a completionist then this is probably gonna be one of more simpler games that you can 100%. I don't like giving out number scores for things but if I had to then I'd say this is a high 7, low 8. Overall, good game, I liked it but I didn't love it like everyone else.

139812447.review: Apart from a couple of really unfair sections, where you have no way of avoiding death traps unless you already know what's coming, the game is really, really good. It's also incredibly beautiful.

139798109.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest is an "every frame a painting" style game, and the music and sound design matches the art in its quality. The movement is very smooth - from the painfully restrictive state at the beginning of the game, it gets ridiculously round and multifaceted towards the end. It really is a platforming game, with added combat elements (compared to Blasphemous, Hollow Knight, Gato Roboto etc where the combat is just as if not more important than the parkour). 

What sours the impression somewhat is the writing. While the platforming is satisfyingly challenging, the story is basically on the level of childrens television - kinda like the Trine series. We solved all our issues with the power of friendship!- and then it ends... rather unimaginative for an IP of this quality.

Further, the dialogue of the wisp and the tree might as well not be there, as it brings nothing to the table (kinda just worsens the game, really). To compare with a different but similar game - Hyper Light Drifter has literally no dialogue in the entire game, and handles story and would-be dialogue exclusively through images and a wonderfully executed visual design. Gris has no dialogue to speak of either, and it probably functions better for it. Having what's essentially just the wisp from Zelda constantly explaining everything in all-too-concrete terms (we need to go to Fire Mountain and get the Fire Stone!) ruins the immersion more than it helps the player - it's a reminder that it's all Just A Game, and after experiencing HLD (or any other game in which the dialogue is handled in a less obtruse manner), a "Just A Game"-game just doesn't cut it. At least not for a perfect 10.

But while there's some whacky bits in the story... won't lie, I was kinda touched by the final scene.

First impressions after just finishing the game - definitely in the upper half of the X/10.

139576132.review:
[h1] One of the Best Metroidvanias Ever Made [/h1]

The title says it all. And unbelievably fantastic representation of the Metroidvania genre with more of a focus on platforming than combat. A must-buy in my book.

Story-wise, this game has only a handful of characters with no dialogue in-between them (other than narration) and yet somehow puts every AAA game to shame with how emotionally impactful it is. A lot of people found the first 10 minutes of the game to be a tear jerker and the ending is somewhat similar. We witness character growth between 2 of the characters and honestly its great how nice and minimal yet well done the story is. 

The game is one of the most beautiful 2D games I've ever played (and the sequel is even better). There's more of an emphasis on platforming than combat in the gameplay and that is mirrored by the level design as well. This is opposed to Hollow Knight - which is more combat based - and Metroid - which is very mixed. It also lacks any of the RPG elements in Symphony of the Night and instead takes a Metroid approach, which is totally fine. There are plenty of times throughout the game when I thought "That has to be all the skills in the game... right?" they hit you with another one completely changing the way you can traverse some areas. 

Unlike Hollow Knight, which I found to be almost devoid of power-ups, this game has plenty. Although I will say by the end of the game they aren't nearly as useful. The game is chalked full with every corner having invisible walls, and short little puzzles to unlock more health, magic, or XP. 

Since combat is not nearly as important in this game its understandable that combat is also the weakest part of the game. You get an auto lock-on projectile, a ground-pound, and an one that lets you bounce off of enemy projectiles. But since combat isn't that important they never really throw that many enemies at you too often and the boss battles are non-existent. The sequel improves on this aspect considerably.

The Definitive Edition adds two optional new areas to explore and that have power-ups as well. Its not that huge of a difference, and so I wouldn't say its absolutely necessary to buy the Definitive Edition. 

All in all, this is one of the best Metroidvania games of all time. I've played every Metroid game and would have to put this up there next to Super Metroid in my opinion (not as revolutionary though, just enjoyment wise). You're getting a good 8 hours of gameplay with fantastic art direction and great potential for exploration. And for the price it's at? [b] 100% you must purchase this game! [/b] The sequel is also just as good and improves upon many of the mechanics in the game.

139575830.review:
I am very very very very conflicted on this review. I wish i could vote mixed instead of thumbs up or down. They attempted to make a game to please platformer fans and metroidvania fans all at once which just doesnt work. I saw a steam review that stated "Your average platformer fan doesnt want to be drip fed power ups and be lost with tedious back tracking while your metroidvania fans dont desire the more linear powers that have to be given to appease the platforming. It just doesnt mix." and as a platformer fan myself i have to agree

The pros:
- Amazing art design and world
- Emotional story that never fails to tug at your heartstrings 
- Decent combat with exceptional parkour.
- Amazing first 1/3 of the game where i would make no changes.

Hugely massive con:
- The level design is absurdly bad even for a metroidvania game. After the first of the 3 artifacts i had to look up a specific guide for where i was every 15 minutes and this is apparently really common. Every quick 1 minute long "here is the dumb way to go/solution" video got posted by unknown channels but they all got 200-400k views. That is insane that so many people have to flock to help because the level design is something to be ashamed of. Even on repeat i would probably be lost replaying an that is no fun so i decided to not go for 100% even tho i love the story and the actual gameplay.
- Another massive problem on my run was the developers not level designing for agility upgrades, since i got triple jump early i entered areas i should not of even been in...... i was in misty woods before the first artifact and another time i got lost because a crusher also shot me through the floor and i thought it was supposed to happen. When you unlock new areas too the game wants you to go to a specific area that isnt even near the new area because there was a crack in the ceiling that you can now break even tho the room was forgettable and you ran right past it and its in the middle of the map. Sometimes no hand holding just leads to sloppy level design


TLDR: Story is amazing and so is the artstyle and gameplay but idk if i would recommend due to lazy level design and unforseen player upgrades that can get you lost with no sense of how to return. I will give a thumbs up but i would suggest watching a walkthrough for the story instead. Literally cant give a thumbs down because the story rocked



EDIT AFTER 100%. Opinion on level design hasn't changed and this game is a nightmare for achievement hunters. No stone unturned is literally bugged, good thing i had a back up save to do a certain strategy to raise my secret count. Be careful if going for 100%, so many bugs. Even having any save game on your files where you bought an ability will void the achievement to do a run without buying abilities.... Had to download someone else's save online to correct that issue.

139563864.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest looks cute on the outside but it's a difficult metroidvania platformer, especially on hard mode (I died +650 times). It's tough and challenging so it felt great to figure out how to pass areas. I used a controller, which felt right for this kind of game.

Beautiful environments and a cute story - there's a recurring theme of loss and new beginnings. Nice to see Ori go from a fragile weakling to a powerhouse over the course of the journey, which doesn't feel like a slog. Finished the game in 11-12 hours.

I do have a few gripes though. First off, there's no new game plus. I learned it's not uncommon for players who've played hard mode to attain only around half the upgrades by the end, which is what happened in my case. I discovered a power that's pretty much used to unlock doors to get stat and ability boosts just before I finished the game... by that point there's no incentive to level up unless you like returning to the places you've been and goofing around, which I don't.

This could just be an issue with my laptop but I also had an issue with the audio/video sync during cutscenes.

Looking forward to play the sequel in hopes that the devs brought more of what was great about this game and improved the pace of levelling through the game.

139277110.review:
I actually genuinely enjoyed Ori and the blind forest, alongside its sequel, Ori and the will of the wisp, these games have inventive platforming mechanics, open level design that allows players to tackle scenarios in marginally different ways to each other so as to increase the level of satisfaction in the completion of its challenges and oh yeah they are pretty looking.

Unfortunately, they do not stand up to scrutiny and this mainly comes down to the unnecessary and inelegant inclusion of its metroidvania elements, which hinders the platforming core that is the crucial aspect that makes Ori stand out from the rank and file. 

Firstly, we must acknowledge that platformer fans and metroidvania fans are more dissimilar than they are alike, in spite of the latter´s frequent inclusion of the former´s elements. This means that by making a platformer metroidvania hybrid, the developers had to juggle several conflicting priorities that arose from trying to please both crowds, ultimately culminating into an experience that does not know what it wants to be.

Platformer fans appreciate and thrive off the inclusion of fun movement mechanics, engaging and demanding levels and the knowledge that they are improving at their parkouring skills, whereas Metroidvania fans tend to appreciate more extrinsic rewards, where improvement and progress is dictated by the constant drip-feed of power-ups, stat buffs and keys, whether they be power ups or just resi style keys, to open up the world. In essence, one thrives off the challenge faced and the dexterity acquired to match such odds where as the other is more concerned about the power fantasy.

Moon studios has NOT juggled these two divergent demands sufficiently deftly. The metroidvania world is both too simple to satisfy metroidvania fans but enough of a time waster with lack of relevant obstacles to bore even the most patient platformer fanatic. The mechanics are fun, but they are never pushed to their true limit by the level design, souring the experience for platforming fans, yet being too complex for metroidvania fans that want the progression in the game to level out the difficulty rather than feel the technical demand ramp up as the game progresses.

Even when given the chance to mitigate these conflicting demands by having the metroidvania platformer hybrid become more than the sum of its parts via tasteful mixing of platforming and metroidvania ideas, moon studios fails to deliver.

All optional secrets lead to a power up and little else, rather than, let´s say more fully fledged levels that rewards players who engage with the game and expand the initial scope of the world map, aspects that both types of players would greatly appreciate. Or how there´s a dearth of glitchless sequence breaking that the metroidvania genre is known for, creating diverse path for all the players, yet the game prefers to railroad you constantly.

What hurts most about any game, is not its faults but rather its missed potential. When I see what moon studios could have achieved with Ori, but ended up compromising with a middle of the road release,  I can´t help but tear up. 

Feel free to buy the game, I am sure it will last you a playthrough; now as to anything beyond that? Well, I have my doubts there, that´s for sure.

139185088.review:
This is a near-perfect metroidvania for me. It's fun to explore, get lost, backtrack, unlock new abilities and rediscover how you can interact with each of the many diverse environments. Upon completion, I got a very satisfying feeling of accomplishment and well-spent time.

I'm a slow player, but it took me around 15h to 100% the map and get all achievements that are available on the first play-through. At first, I thought it's a pity that the map doesn't have markers, but in the end I was able to get all collectibles and discover all secrets without getting bored with repetitive backtracking or looking up online guides. Once you unlock some abilities or beat some "bosses", it becomes easier to traverse other environments, which makes it faster and less boring to go back and get some collectibles that were unavailable before. 

The game is pretty well-balanced in my opinion: there were plenty of challenges that required multiple attempts and a combination of puzzle-solving with precision, but it was never so hard that I would rage-quit. I also liked chase challenges instead of boss-fights, just a personal preference, but it was more fun and less anxiety for me.

I usually play several games in parallel, depending on the mood, but once I started Ori, I couldn't stop until I finished it. Surprisingly, this wasn't because of an engaging story, but because of the fun gameplay and overall very enjoyable experience. I think the story-telling just didn't click with me (the god-like tree talking), but the animation in cut-scenes was amazing, just like watching a professionally made short animated film. The animation in the game itself is beautiful, it has an original style, detailed backgrounds and interesting character designs. I played it on a Steam Deck, but always connected it to the big TV screen to enjoy the visuals in details. And to just add to the complete experience, there is a beautiful, elaborate soundtrack, it really creates a great atmosphere and doesn't get old after playing for a while.

P.S. the "Definitive Edition" has a fascinating collection of early prototype sketches and videos of early development. It was fun to watch after playing the game and astounding to see the progress from ideation to the final result.

138446328.review:
I remember buying this game for my sister a few years back. Didn't think much of it at the time, but I thought it would be a nice gift for her. I remember seeing her playing it from time to time, the message indicating that she'd started playing it popping up on the corner of my screen. There was always a certain small pride in seeing that, because to me it meant that she was enjoying my gift.
Last September she committed suicide.

After everything had more or less settled down from that, I sat down and booted up her computer. All that was on there was Chrome, Steam, Word, and a few games. One of them, of course, was Core keeper.
She had played this game to pieces, clocking over 170 hours and owning practically everything the game had to offer. She had used every square inch to its maximum potential, and was making ridiculous amounts of loot. It was only then did I see just how much she loved my present. No other game she played quite captured her affection as much as this one. None of her friends really knew about it, however; it seems like she preferred to keep it to herself. Like it was her own little bit of heaven she could turn to whenever she wanted.

And because of that, I can't help but smile whenever I play this game.

I cannot recommend it enough; every bit of hard work the developer put into this masterpiece shows in every single aspect. The music is catchy and memorable (I'll often find myself humming certain tunes from it), the world feels lived-in and natural, and the gameplay is incredibly laid back and enjoyable. It's hard to stop once I get invested in the game; minutes can easily turn into several hours. And now, with the multiplayer beta, I play for even longer with my friends, each of us dedicated to our desired jobs. Most of all, however, we're all just happy to be together.

Even the story was touching to me, although usually I don't care for story. Bugs or crashes? I encountered zero. The only thing that was mildly annoying was some boss fights where you will have to replay an unneccesarily lenghty part of the sequence when you fail. They could have respawned you a bit further in there. But it's not a big deal since there aren't too many boss fights. And while challening, they are not overly difficult just for the sake of difficulty, like in Dark Souls or Hollow Knight. They're a good mix of challenge and fun, and this applies also to the usual enemy encounters. Overall, this is the type of game that you get when brilliant game design and excellent programming come together. You must play this game. And then, you must also play its sequel "Ori and the Will of the Wisps".

138202763.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest: DE is easily one of my favorite games of all time, if not my favorite of all time period. I've beaten the game so many times now, and three times on its One-Life mode--once on my Switch, once on my friend's Steam account, and most recently again on my own Steam account (with 100% completion!). So even though I'm listed as 23 hours into this game, I've played it for many more.

There are many things that make this game wonderful in my mind, but I'll give an overview of my favorite things in a non-spoiler fashion.

TL;DR: Give this game a shot; it's well worth it.

GAMEPLAY (Excellent!)
First off, Ori and the Blind Forest has easily some of the best movement in any platformer I've played. Ori feels very responsive.  In the early game, Ori feels good enough as you just run and jump through the map. But, as the game progresses, the various abilities you unlock allow you to soar across the map with high speed and high precision. Ori spends a ton of time in the air, but you always have a ton of control.

The game isn't easy, either. You're given a wide variety of abilities that string together in very interesting ways, and the game expects you to learn how to use them and use them well. The challenges the game throws at you demand a certain degree of mastery over the controls and Ori's skills, as you'd desire for a platformer. Given how I've played it to death, the difficult is somewhat diminished in my mind now, but I do recall that I took hundreds of deaths in my first playthrough--a good thing in my mind as a gamer who likes a challenge. But, even if you prefer easier experiences, you're allowed to save (almost) anytime and anywhere, so you can typically lock in your progress after clearing a difficult challenge only once. This allows the game to be difficult without being too punishing. The game also has an Easy mode for inexperienced/relaxed players.

As a side note--you may have heard Blind Forest described as a metroidvania. This is nominally true, but it honestly it plays fairly linearly; if you're looking for a distinctly metroidvania experience, this isn't quite the game to find that. Most of the metroidvania parts will be missed entirely unless you're going for 100% completion, and even then they play more as a "come back to this area later with a new ability to explore this small nook with bonus rewards."

I say all that to say: Treat Ori like a linear platformer game. that's where it shines, and it shines brightly.

STORY (Simple but Heartfelt--no spoilers, I promise)
Because I'm promising no spoilers, I won't say much. All I'll say is that the story is deeply heartfelt, which I always love in a game. It's not particularly deep, so if you're looking for a story that will leave you with something to chew on for an extended period of time, you won't really find it here. Instead, the story is simple--which is the right fit for what Blind Forest is--and it ties the game together beautifully.

GRAPHICS (Beautiful!)
This game is gorgeous. If I recall correctly, every environment was painted by hand and then imported into the game. 

MUSIC (Stellar!)
Gareth Coker is a stellar composer, and it shows in this game. I do think he outdid even this soundtrack in Will of the Wisps, but I still find myself pulling up the Blind Forest soundtrack on Spotify here and there. Every track is memorable in its own way, and helps the game really hit home with the wide range of emotions it explores throughout.

REPLAYABILITY AND PLAY TIME (Depends on you! But probably honestly not too replayable.)
In my mind, replayability is a non-factor for a game's quality, and way too much emphasis is placed upon it in modern game reviews. But that's a side rant that I'll spare you for now. I'll just cover this since I know some people care about that sort of thing.

Ori and the Blind Forest's replayability is contingent upon the type of gamer you are. If you like beating a game once and then calling yourself done, Ori will give you an experience that's loads of fun but won't last too long--maybe around seven to ten hours on a first playthrough, depending on your skill with plaformers? (Again, I've played this game to death, so I don't have a good sense of this anymore, but my playthroughs nowadays tend to take three hours to 100% the game--given that I die infrequently, if at all, and already know where all the secrets are.) If you want to get all the achievements, including the ones related to One-Life mode, you'll need to replay the game several times to do so. Again, given the game's linear nature, the repeated playthroughs will be similar to one another, so most of the replay value comes in refining your abilities in the game and watching yourself improve.

In a nutshell, if you get a kick out of grinding and watching yourself improve your skills--and won't be TOO devastated by dying to an instakill two-and-a-half hours into a One Life run of the game for the final achievement (and there are many, MANY instakills in Blind Forest)--Ori has a ton of replayability. Otherwise, don't expect too much from repeat playthroughs.

CONCLUSION (BUY THIS GAME!)
BUY THIS GAME! It's well worth the price, well worth the time, and well worth the tears if you happen to be an emotional gamer.

-----

*Yes, I know Ori is canonically ungendered. But also, I've always thought of him as male, not to mention that his voice gets deeper in Will of the Wisps--a distinct indicator of puberty in males. ;)

First things first: The game is in my opinion best experienced with a gamepad.

138157869.review:
I think I came up with a pretty good test for detecting a psychopath. All you need to is:

- Chain someone to your gaming chair;
- Make them play first ten minutes of Ori and the Blind Forest;
- Listen to any "awwww" sounds. 

Seriously, this game is so awwww-some that I don't think most human beings have a capacity to withhold such overwhelming cuteness, unless something is terribly wrong with them. Going through Ori's intro sequence is like watching a duckling that falls to sleep next to a bunch of small kittens. This game enchants you quickly, sucks you into its world in a matter of seconds and just like someone who failed the aforementioned test, it will never let you forget it.

In case it wasn't obvious before and by some miracle you've missed all the screenshots, I'll state the obvious: it's a TRULY BEAUTIFUL GAME. Vividly drawn landscapes and happy fluid animations are parts of its charm, but combined with an ABSOLUTELY GENIUS SOUNDTRACK create a true feast for the senses; one that will only be depreciated by inventing edible strawberry-flavored monitors. The simple act of just pacing around is a great audio-visual experience, but along with the looks comes a surprisingly well-written story, giving our movements a deeper purpose. Despite its simplicity and Disneyesque qualities, it's told quite well, shifting the moods along the ride. While Ori is generally a joyful experience, it can also be full of tension or filled with grim solemnity. Each area has its own mood, making the world feel incredibly alive.

Game's great atmosphere and soothing colors are important for other reasons, namely calming us down. Ori has a QUITE HIGH DIFFICULTY LEVEL, that's usually somewhere between "that's gonna be a challenge" and "Oh, hell no". The whole game area is one giant level, divided into smaller areas, creating something that gaming PhDs would call "Metroidvania-inspired platformer". While at first the road ahead is quite easy and straightforward, Ori quickly learns a bunch of new abilities that broaden the area of exploration to the size of New Caledonia. Curiosity and good eyes are often rewarded with the additional XP and power-ups, so there's a good reason to stray often from our path, but it's also incredibly easy to get lost in the huge sprawling environment. And sometimes you're going to waste time trying to beat a challenge that looks do-able, but it can only be done with certain skills that you don't yet possess. Some sections are just also old-fashionably hard, especially when you had the misfortune of saving the game with a low amount of health. When you painstakingly try to make your way through the level for the 20th time even the beauty of the world around can be lost. 

Despite giving us a harsh time now and then, Ori and the Blind Forest remains a PHENOMENAL game. The definitive edition is probably the best way to start the adventure with it, since it offers more content, new abilities, option to adjust difficulty and various quality of life improvements, etc., but you still won't be disappointed by going for the original version. It is still one of the best games I had the pleasure of playing and after 200 titles I'm not stating this lightly. It's an incredible experience and a total must-play. 10/10. My thumb is up so high that I'm going to look like a Statue of Liberty on this one!

138116176.review:
I wanted to like this game, there's just a host of factors that have caused this game to be little more than infuriating. I played the entire game, start to finish, and completed all achievements not requiring subsequent runs, so I feel like I have a good understanding of the game.

To start, I'll admit that the art is objectively, beautiful. However, with so much detail on the screen, combined with the size of your character often makes it hard to understand what is hitting you. Projectiles from enemies can either camoflague into the backdrop, or just be small enough that you can't see them among the many other things on the screen. I understand that the size of your character is supposed to make the world seem bigger, however I feel it negatively impacts the game to an unreasonable level.

The movement in this game felt like shit to me the entire time. This game is some of the worst implementations of wall jumping and double jumping that I've experienced in my entire life. I see many ways in which this game strives to be unique, with the mechanics being one of them. Admittedly, some of the concepts I like, like the Bash movement allowing you to launch yourself off of enemies. Some I wasn't fond of, but I understand the purpose for, such as the saving. Saving in this game is much more of a risk reward mechanic, and while I personally don't like the way saving works, I don't think the decision to treat in game saving in the way it is is a particularly bad thing. However, referencing back to the double jump, it seems that this mechanic was changed from the typical double jump system just for the sake of being different. Being different doesn't automatically equate to being better. If the goal was to make the game harder, you can do this much more effectively through more difficult platforming sections based on environment, rather than player control. 

While I did praise the "Bash" system earlier, I found that the hitbox within which I could activate the ability was spotty, especially during the tree climbing segment. I found many hitboxes to be illogical, be it some of the spikes or enemies jumping next to you and failing to indicate the area in which you are able to be damaged.

The damage scaling in this game really doesn't make sense to me. When you have 3 hit points at the beginning of the game, spikes deal 2 damage. As you progress, you gain more hit points, but the damage from spikes and other enemies scales with you. Supposedly this system really forces you to explore and find as many secrets as you can to raise your health, but it still is an illogical way to scale difficulty throughout the game, at least to the degree that it is. 

The story for this game to me is, for lack of a better word, average. Without spoiling what happens, it is at first glance a meaningful story, however if you put even an ounce of thought into it, the story is in no way deep or special. I don't even think this game necessarily needs to have a sprawling beautiful story, but people treat it like its the greatest story ever told by man, while in reality it's on par with a Disney movie. 

The world building in this game feels highly disconnected. While each of the locations is beautiful, they all feel very separate from each other. You have your typical water section. Your lava section. Your forest section. Your dark section. Each of these environments in an echo chamber is great, but as I played through the game I felt no sense of coherence between the areas that had been created. 

Finally, the combat system is just all around disappointing. No thought has to be put into any sort of fighting throughout the whole game, it's just repeated left clicking. This would be fine of combat was sparse, but there is frequently enemies that you need to take care of, and the clicking becomes monotonous. 

In short, I feel like there's just always a better game for you to be playing if you feel the urge to play Ori. If you want world building and combat, play Hollow Knight. If you want platforming and a meaningful story, play Celeste. I'm hoping I enjoy Will of the Wisps more than this one.

137957618.review:
Un metroidvania que no innova en nada, cuyo plataformeo es difícil hasta el punto de la desesperación, pero con una OST que salva la mitad del juego. Directamente, esperaba MÁS. Dentro reseña!

Llevo con este juego en mi biblioteca años, de hecho tenía la versión normal a la que jugué de salida como una hora. Y ahora ha sido cuando me lo he pasado en Steam Deck (60 fps con todo en alto, sin bajones, perfecto) y me ha quedado un mal sabor de boca.

Es un metroidvania con una ost preciosa que tienes en la cabeza todo el rato. La historia, aunque más simple que los teletubbies, suficiente para que te de pena los protagonistas o el propio Ori. Pero ya está, texto en pantalla para ir contando el desarrollo.

El mapa se divide en biomas aunque da la sensación de que todo se repite constantemente, cada pincho, enemigo o roca. El mapa está muy bien conectado pero me da una pereza después de las 6 horas para ver los créditos, volver para recoger todo y mejorar a Ori al máximo. No le veo ningún incentivo. Ori posee un ataque único, 3 ramas de habilidades con pasivas incluidas. Y adquirirá poderes para poder volver a las zonas y continuar por caminos que hemos dejado. Incluso bucear. Mecánicas de cualquier metroidvania y sencillos.

Los tipos de enemigos son muy escasos, pero muy mucho. Bosses apenas. El tramo final es de lo más jodido que he visto en un metroidvania en cuestión de plataformeo al uso. Una mecánica única e interesante es que Ori tiene barra de vida y de maná. Con el maná podremos poner puntos de guardados libres a nuestro antojo, es decir, nosotros hacemos los checkpoints. Una mecánica bastante curiosa y única. Pero quitando eso el juego es un popurrí de cosas, si bien bonitas, bastante simples para un juego de este estilo. No sientes una progresión inmensa. Tampoco entiendo el bombo de este juego, sinceramente. Blasphemous, Indivisible, Ender Lillies, incluso el Yokus Island me parecieron más interesantes y no se me hicieron bola.

Dicho esto, lo puedo recomendar en su justa medida, pero si pienso en un metroidvania, este Ori sería de los últimos de la lista. La ventaja es que está tirado de precio. Acompaña a Ori para salvar a los elementos que forman su mundo. Gracias por leer! <3

137907647.review:
Cool metroidvania that de-emphasizes combat - as you have an infinite ranged attack that automatically seeks out enemies - and instead focuses on gorgeous atmospheric environments and its novel system of placing your own checkpoints. The interconnected regions of the forest are visually and mechanically distinct, though none of the game's stylistic choices break the mold. The level of background detail rarely affects readability, but that problem is far more pronounced when it comes to enemy projectiles, which often blend in with your projectiles or the drops from enemies, all of them being effectively just moving glowy bits.

My biggest criticism would be that the game does not unlock its full fun potential until your character, Ori, does; that is, until you've unlocked a solid selection of movement options. Once that has happened and you've become accustomed to the controls, even returning to previous sections of the map becomes a blast.

As for the story... I'm not crying you're crying

This is a complicated game to recommend. The OST is absolutely stunning, the art is very pretty and the story is touching and well executed. But the levels, man. 
I almost quit because of one sequence that required either near perfect inputs for a long stretch of time, or to previously grind like a madman to spec out the protagonist's mobility. The difficulty of this game comes mostly from trial-and-error, that I despise in videogames as it punishes the player in a first, blind run, and from confusing level design, which again, punishes the player for no reason. Physics are a wee bit junk, first run and I got clipped into a wall and didn't know what to do, it can get a bit grindy, easy mod is normal mode, levels are a bit too set in stone, not a ton of space for creative manouvering unless you unlock another movement ability. 

In the end it was 100% worth it, would buy again. It's a seriously good game with some tearjerking moments and tight movements.
Just make sure it's not a game you play while working 9 to 5, it can be stressful. If you can exercise patience, you'll enjoy it.

137625021.review:
One of the vey few games I've actually finished recently! Not only is the visual style quite appealing, but the difficulty level on normal difficulty is actually NORMAL. If you - like me - ever played Hollow Knight and got frustrated over the difficulty level, then you will love Ori!

It's not based on boss fights, it's all about arcade - jumping, dashing, evading, attacking. No part of the game gets frustrating, even the hardest parts seldom require more than ten tries to get past. Also, the saving system is quite nice: basically, you can spend an Energy point to save before a hard passage and then immediately return to this checkpoint if you fail.

The only critique I might have is that sometimes it requies quite some precision when trying to land on a slim platform - without it, I would probably have died 20% less.

All in all, it's a superb game. I beat it in 10 hours on normal difficulty and spent another 5-6 hours to collect everything and explore the whole map.

10/10 points and I'm looking forward to play the sequel!

This game was long on my wishlist, and now when I am actually playing it, I am disappointed.
It is simply too hard for me. I started with Normal difficulty, then switched to Easy, but it didn't help. I'm a middle-aged casual gamer, and I play with a keyboard and mouse.
The game atmosphere and music are beautiful, story is interesting, but I just could not enjoy the game due to constantly dying (at the moment of writing I had cca. 1700 deaths). That's not fun.
Some parts seem deliberately nasty, it's like the developers just wanted to push the player into rage-quitting. It feels like Meat Boy - if you like such a gameplay, go ahead and prepare yourself for a lot of dying - but that doesn't suit the game's atmosphere IMO.
Many parts of the map are inaccessible until you get the required ability, and I had to learn that by watching youtube walkthroughs.

It's a pity for me because I really wanted to enjoy the game.

Edit: As a completionist, I finally finished the game with > 2100 deaths. What a rage!

137454419.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest is a fun but flawed game. 

The first thing to note is that this game is not Hollow Knight. I've seen it recommended in the same breath, but this game is about platforming not combat- there isn't even a proper boss battle in the entire game. So make sure to go in expecting that. 

Secondly, the game has no checkpoints. Instead you make your own checkpoints consuming the same resource you use in combat. That took me a lot of getting used to, so be sure to save as often as you can to avoid having to redo a difficult section over and over again.

With those two things in mind, Ori is a fun game with an adorable story and artstyle.

game was like 10-12 hours (took me 12 but I'm also not the greatest at platforming and this game has some janky hitboxes). 8/10, both fire areas were insufferable and annoying, the escape sequences were too long, there's areas where you're expected to dodge stuff falling from the sky but their timing and position was RNG which made playing a section over and over so much more annoying because your view is so limited/zoomed in that you can't meaningfully react and dodge the falling shit which led to getting hit which meant basically just letting the game kill you because you need that health for a future section and there's no way to regain health besides finding health pickups or investing a dozen points into a skill and wasting your energy to save the game to regen 2 points of health (which is practically useless because every enemy in the endgame does like over 4 damage minimum. although i did finish on hard mode so maybe the other difficulties may have less damage dealt). also the janky hitboxes made climbing so much more annoying than it needed to be. 

anyway, it's fun! it's a fun little metroidvania, wish there was more to do, more enemies instead of reskins, and some intended paths were more clear, especially in Sorrow's Pass because i was stuck there for like 30 minutes (tbf it was my fault because i forgot an interaction you could do but still, only time i had to look up a guide), but I still got most of the stuff done (76% completion) without really trying. not gonna 100% because I can't be bothered but I had fun! if you like metroidvanias but don't want much combat deeper than spamming a button or holding it down for a big attack, this will probably be right up your alley. the platforming is really fun and i'm excited to see how the sequel builds on this.

137210074.review:
9/10 superb metroidvania with an emphasis on platforming reminiscent of DK. Amazing gameplay, visuals, music, sound, and overall atmosphere. Great level/area design and exploration. Fast travel is well-done and revisiting areas to find missed secrets doesn't feel like a chore. Overall, it's a real joy to play.

Three things you should not expect from this game:
1. Combat. You take out plenty of naughty critters but the emphasis is on platforming more than combat. Notably, there are special platforming sequences instead of bosses in the usual sense.
2. Puzzles. There are a few little areas that take a some planning or thought. This aspect of the game could have been taken to the next level while staying true to the overall feel of the game.
3. Story. There's not a lot going on with the storyline. What's there is heartfelt and fleshes out the characters a little.

137204651.review:
[i] For context, I 100%  the achievements [/i]

Ori and the Bind Forest was my first metro-vanilla 2D game. This is a perfect game if you want to get into the metro-vanilla genre. Here are my pros and cons 

[h1] Pros [/h1]

Music - The music of games is something that I do not pay attention to much in many games, but this game is special. The music score is so incredible and makes some areas feel very atmospheric.

Art Style - The art style of this game has held up incredibly well considering that it is a 9-year-old game at the time of writing this. The art style of fantastic, and the world and the characters are made incredibly well. 

The World - Each part of the world has its unique look and thing to it. Each part is unique and enjoyable to explore 

The 100% achievement grind - This game will take you around 25 - 30 hours to get all the achievements to expect for the super hard 4. They are the following

-Complete a game in under 3 hours
-Complete a game without using any skill points
-Complete a game without dying once
-Complete a game in the One Life difficulty (This achievement was added in the definitive edition of the game. I would recommend just doing the One Life difficulty to complete the final two in one game)

The achievements that I mentioned force to you play at your best and are hard to complete. They probably added 30 hours to my playtime. I just completed the last two today, and I broke down crying because of how happy I was. What I like how this game has incredibly rare and incredibly hard achievements. Of course, you can install SAM and get all the achievements with a click of a button, but deep down, you will feel guilty. 

[h1] Cons [/h1]

Combat - The game is not combat-focused, which could be a positive to some, and negative to others. Anyway, the few pieces of combat that this game does have is pretty shallow. You just spam your attack button while stomping when you get that ability. Also, the game has no bosses, only escape sections which are very good 

The amount of One-Shots - This con is what made the last two achievements so incredibly hard. There are many, many things that one shot you, no matter how much health you have. Some things do a ton of damage that one hit kills you. 

[h1] My Final Thoughts [/h1]

This is a simple, yet incredibly good metro-vanilla-type game that I would highly recommend you try. You will have fun playing, and be immersed in the atmosphere. However, if you do not 100% of the achievements, it might be expensive due to the amount of playtime. I would recommend waiting until this game is on sale because you can get really good deals. I got the first and second games for only 11 dollars, which is a steal.

8/10

137037599.review:
Really beautiful game with fluid, tight mechanics. I don't usually like platformers but the movement is so smooth that it makes this game a joy to play. The projectile redirect mechanic is one of the most fun abilities I've used in a game. All the upgrades feel natural and play into each other to make your movement increasingly complex and satisfying. I didn't think I'd really like this game but I ended up binging most of it in a day, so I think they achieved something pretty special with how this game controls.

The devs also clearly put a lot of work into the animations and responsiveness of the environment. So many things react to the physics of the world such as floating rocks temporarily sinking under your weight. It really makes the game world feel alive. Coupled with the relaxing, lovely music and art direction, the game looks gorgeous.

My one major complaint is the amount of camera shake, especially during the escape sequences. It does help add to the tension of the moment, but the amount of shake is completely overkill and makes for a frustrating experience when I can't see what's going on. And the escape sequences in general are just stressful and un-fun because death means starting from the beginning. It can get really tiring. Not to mention it can take the wind out of the final moments of the game because instead of feeling the thrill of an exciting escape, I just felt relief that the annoyance was over.

[h1]My Rating: 4/5[/h1]

136761180.review:
Let me start off by saying this is a very beautiful game. 

From the music to the graphics to the atmosphere the game presents is a masterpiece in motion.  the mystical forests, marshes, and caverns shimmer with radiance. It's like watching a painting of light dance about the screen. And Gareth Coker's haunting score keeps you enthralled for the entire story. When I hear the orchestral score that plays when you're climbing the Ginso tree it sends chills down my spine... in a good way.

The controls, especially when playing with an Xbox One controller, are very responsive and fluid. There was no delay whatsoever in input, and this is very important because the game has a massive number of platform jumping puzzles sending you bouncing all over the place where even the slightest error will send you careening down to your death. 

The game is pretty forgiving when it comes to life and death, allowing you to try again as many times as you like. There's also a system that lets you save your game almost anywhere. Without this I would have quit the game long ago.

But, yes, I wholeheartedly recommend this game as long as you are okay with nimble-fingered jumping puzzles. If that's your kind of game then this will not disappoint.

136571101.review:
The game follows the story of Ori, a spirit who lives in the forest of Nibel. Ori is tasked with restoring the forest to its former glory, but must first navigate through perilous environments and defeat powerful enemies. Along the way, Ori meets several characters who offer guidance and aid in the quest.

One of the most impressive aspects of "Ori and the Blind Forest" is its art direction. The backgrounds are simply gorgeous, and the character designs are both charming and unique. The game's lighting effects are also top-notch, creating an immersive atmosphere that draws players in.

In addition to its stunning visuals, the game features a beautiful and haunting soundtrack that perfectly complements the action on screen. The music ranges from sweeping orchestral pieces to more intimate piano compositions, and is one of the highlights of the game.

Finally, the game's story is both touching and powerful. The themes of loss, redemption, and sacrifice are woven throughout the game, and the characters are all well-written and sympathetic. By the end of the game, players will feel a real sense of attachment to Ori and the other characters.

Overall, "Ori and the Blind Forest" is an incredible achievement in game design. It offers a challenging platforming experience that is both visually and emotionally stunning. It is a must-play for anyone who loves games that are both beautiful and meaningful.

136399742.review:
Juego completado enteramente en Steam Deck.

Precioso juego de ese género tan guay hoy en día aceptado como "metroidvania". Siempre leí buenas críticas del juego, y llamándome mucho la atención tanto por el estilo de juego como por su estética, pues decidí darle un tiento. Si bien es cierto que al principio no me pareció para tanto, la verdad es que en este género me pasa que una vez superada una barrera mental inicial luego me suelo picar mucho y me encanta ir a completar todos los secretos y mapas. Y así fue y así me la he gozado.

Eres una especie de zarigüeya albina amiga de un familiar de Totoro que tiene que salvar al bosque de un búho muy malo. La historia se presenta en pequeños recuerdos animados preciosistas mientras vas avanzando en el juego. No es que interese mucho pero está bien y es muy "cute". Salto, doble salto, triple salto, planear, agarre especial, patada culona, nadar sin respirar, ataque pikachu... las típicas mejoras de este tipo de juegos que irán haciéndonos más fácil o accesible el camino para llegar al siguiente punto deseado. En este juego no hay jefes como tal (un par de combates anodinos) y las fases un poquito más especiales son como de escapar o plataformeo. Por mi parte está bien así y es coherente con el estilo de juego.

Lo cierto es que a nivel jugable es muy bueno, y da gusto manejar al bichillo por los diferentes escenarios. El juego se va pasando rápido y cuando me he querido dar cuenta de que lo estaba acabando (buscando ese ansiado 100% de completado con todos los tesoritos y mejoras y mapa) pues la verdad es que se me hizo corto. Ahora bien, el tiempo de partida me ha marcado 17 horas (así que de corto nada) y en Steam marca 22 horas (así que supongo que esa diferencia son 5 horas de ser un paquete).

Destacar su diseño de niveles, siempre amable y correcto como para saber que habrá algo por ahí que nos ayude a seguir, así como a nivel estético que es de lo mejorcito que he visto en el medio. La música también es preciosa y acompaña fenomenal sin hacerse monótona (al revés). Una gozada para los sentidos (tacto sería suave, gusto probablemente a sandía o fresa, y olor a jazmín).

En la Deck el juego va de maravilla. La batería dura bastante y obviamente todo a tope de opciones gráficas. La única pega, no admite formato 16:10 de pantalla, esto es toca jugar con las dos franjitas negras arriba y abajo. Me ha gustado que se puede manejar con la cruceta. Es una chorrada pero yo lo agradezco para este tipo de juegos.

En un tiempecillo obviamente caerá su segunda parte.

Nota final: Muy recomendado. Si te gusta el género metroidvania se convierte en obligatorio.

Para mí en ese género está por detrás de Hollow Knight (que es la repanocha) y yo diría que también (esto ya es muy subjetivo) un poquito por detrás de algún Castlevania tipo Aria of Sorrow o Bloodstained (me mola más ese rollo oscuro y con un poquito de roleo).

🔲 Mala
🔲 Mediocre 
🔲 Buena
☑️ Hermosa

[i]Aunque haya pocas ocasiones en las que aparezca la música, las veces que pasa son maravillosas, se sienten llena de vida y combinan perfecto con la temática del juego.[/i]

[h1]HISTORIA[/h1]

🔲 No tiene historia
🔲 Simplona y/o genérica 
🔲 Rebuscada y confusa
☑️ Mediocre
🔲 Bien escrita
🔲 Intrigante y atrapante

[i]No muy intrigante pero cumple bien con el papel de llevarte por el mundo del juego y no aburrirte.[/i]

[h1]PERSONAJES[/h1]

☑️ Vacíos 
🔲 Mediocres 
🔲 Bien logrados 
🔲 Muy carismáticos 

[i]No existen personajes suficientes en el juego como para analizar.[/i]

[h1]AMBIENTACIÓN Y ATENCIÓN AL DETALLE[/h1]

🔲 Pobre
🔲 Normal
☑️ Buena inmersión 
🔲 Perfecta

[i]Las decoraciones e iluminación de cada zona del mapa logra crear una clara diferencia de ambiente entre cada una de ellas, cumpliendo un buen papel para lograr que cada zona se sienta única aparte de mezclarse bien con elementos del gameplay.[/i]

[h1]REQUISITOS PARA SER DISFRUTABLE[/h1]

☑️ Bajo
🔲 Medio
🔲 Alto
🔲 Ultra

[h1]DURACIÓN[/h1]

☑️ Corto 
🔲 Normal
🔲 Largo 
🔲 Muy largo
🔲 Sin fin

[i]El juego me duró aproximadamente 6 horas y media completando la historia principal, explorando bien cada zona para obtener algunas de las recompensas de estas.[/i]

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]

🔲 Muy aburrido
🔲 Difícil de divertirse 
☑️ Pasable
🔲 Divertido
🔲 Muy disfrutable

[i]Aunque la variedad de enemigos sea abundante, las maneras que tienes para enfrentarlos es muy reducida, las pocas mejoras que puedes desbloquear en el árbol de habilidades solo afectan ligeramente al combate o parkour. Como plataformero es excelente, a medida que avanzamos desbloqueas movimientos o trucos que te permiten explorar zonas que antes no podías y así es como progresas en general, está bien diseñado y da una sensación de estar recompensado por recoger estas habilidades.[/i]

[h1]REJUGABILIDAD[/h1]

🔲 Es una experiencia única
☑️ Para completar logros 
🔲 Para ver otras interacciones/decisiones 
🔲 Luego de un buen tiempo
🔲 Infinitamente rejugable

[i]Ya que el juego dura poco para el buen contenido que ofrece, no descarto la opción de rejugarlo para obtener algún que otro logro y encarar el juego de otra perspectiva más desafiante.[/i]

[h1]PRECIO (ARGENTINA 💀)[/h1]

🔲 Gratis
🔲 Mucho más barato de lo que debería
🔲 Barato 
🔲 Normal
☑️ Caro
🔲 Demasiado caro para lo que ofrece 

[i]Demasiado caro por su tiempo de duración.[/i]

[h1]VALE LA PENA COMPRAR[/h1]

🔲 No
☑️ Solo en oferta
🔲 Sí

136081493.review:
After starting the game years ago and for some reason abandoning it again quickly, I decided to pick it up again. I had quite high expectations due to the universally good reputation this game has and I have to admit that I was not disappointed. 

The game is beautifully designed and offers a good balance of challenging level design while not being overwhelmingly difficult. The combat is pretty straightforward and while being fun in the beginning, it gets a bit stale towards the end. The save feature is also pretty ingenious and I personally really liked the way it was implemented. I think some people might dislike it but I digress. 

I would've liked a bit more focus on the puzzling aspect in this game and an easier (or more accessible) way to quickly travel from one point of the map to another. Sometimes it also wasn't that intuitive to figure out where you had to go next to progress in the story but these were all minor "flaws" in an otherwise awesome game. 

Overall, a really good platformer with an engaging story, beautiful visuals and above all - a beyond masterful soundtrack.
