136038392.review:
Los gráficos bonitos no hacen grande a un juego, este juego es un ejemplo de eso

El primer tercercio (1/3) del juego es maravilloso, es hermoso y se siente increíblemente fluido, sigues y sigues y no quieres parar por que te sientes feliz por la banda sonora, gráficos y jugabilidad... hasta que entras al segundo tercio (2/3) del juego, específicamente desde la segunda torre, cuando tienes que salir de ella despues de activarla, no hay forma alguna de que tu habilidad como jugador haga que puedas pasártelo a la primera, por que el juego quiere que te golpeen cosas inesquivables para que mueras y tengas que volver a hacerlo ya sabiendo que debes hacer lo que el juego quiere que hagas, no lo que tu como jugador puedas lograr. Todo a partir de ahí (A excepción de la parte del viento en el mapa, la considero la mejor parte del juego) va cuesta abajo, no te explican nada de las mecánicas de las torres y llega a ser frustrante como lo intentas pero no logras decifrar que hacer.
A por cierto, si quieres hacer la tercera torre y luego ir a por cosas en el mapa antes del final, no puedes, la tercera torre es el final del juego, si haces te jodes y no puedes seguir explorando.

Y la historia esta llena de incoherencias a fin de contar una historia triste y de redención, pero estas mismas fallas hacen que no te lo puedas tomar enserio a menos "apagues el cerebro" para disfrutar la historia

Jugare la secuela, si, a pesar de lo que he comentado, quiero jugarlo, tengo la esperanza que hayan aprendido de sus errores y que todo la secuela sea como el primer tercio de este juego en cuanto a disfrute

Ill preface by stating that the graphical style in this game is beautiful, unfortunately...it goes downhill from there. 
The first like 10 minutes of the game is extremely disengaging and a bitnof a slog, where it really isnt a game. Its a narrative setup but displayed in a way that just frustrates the player. Im ok with cutscenes of story elements to kick off a game, but 10 minutes of half forced slow walking and half slow animation, where the transitions are not even clear...it just completely draws you out of the game and was a huge turnoff. 
When the game finaply does start the movement feels ok, and you learn your new abilities and the progression felt nice. The metriodvania style of backtracking with new abilities wasnt awful to start but the game got unclear fast. There were lots of frustrating bits where it doesn't feel like you're dying because you did something wrong, but for something on the games end, which is not fun. 
Overall i was so excited for this game from what id heard about it and the look of it was gorgeous. Unfortunately the product i got was a quick refund after ultimately having next to no fun while playiing it.
Do not recommend.

135625246.review:
I tried to like this game, I really did. But the fact is, it's not really fun.

The visuals are stunning, and the sound design is wonderful, but the overall experience is not rewarding. In many cases you get stuck in repeatedly attempting clearing a sequence of events, where the only way to learn the correct set of move is by dying repeatedly. You always go back to square one (the most recent save) and you get severely punished even for the slightest mistake. For example, if you miss a jump and fall onto spikes, you die with up-to four strikes (I played the normal setting). Given spikes usually cover a large surface, there is no way to avoid getting multiple strikes, which effectively makes it 1-2 strikes before dying.

Experiencing this over and over makes the learning curve really steep, and non-rewarding. And when you finally get to clear a sequence, you are just met with another one of similar difficulty, This gets frustrating and dull eventually, to the point I just did not want to play anymore. I gave up in the second tree quick-action sequence (wind) since it was really long, spikes and geysers are semi random, and there is no way to save mid-way (which means, if you die you have to repeat everything from the start). 

Don't get me wrong, I am well familiar with action-platform-exploration games, and usually am all down with the "git gud" approach. It's just that even when you "git gud" the overall experience is not cathartic at all. It felt more like playing "guitar hero" than playing a platformer.

If you are into challenging, rewarding, action-platform games, I recommend "Hallow Knight" or "Celeste", which are much more rewarding (and boast much better controls). Your time is better spent there than playing this one.

Ori is a dream to control, moving him is so fun and satisfying! The game uses momentum based physics, more akin to Sonic the Hedgehog, so It does take some getting used to for some of the more difficult platforming elements; however, once mastered, moving around is so much fun! My absolute favorite part of the game is the sensational bash ability! A true game changer and what makes Ori unique in my opinion. A must play for any fan of both classic metroidvania games and side-scrolling platformers!

135399149.review: Ori has beautiful visual and music combined with a minor but very emotional story. I sadly just can't recommend the gameplay aspect.My core issue with the game is the checkpoint system, and an overreliance on Trial & Error.Ori has a manual checkpoint mechanic, where you can pop down a respawn point by spending a point of energy. In the early game, this is made frustrating due to you having a very limited amount of energy. It gets better as the game goes on once you have around 5+ to spend, but the game is also incredibly stingy with refills on both your energy and health.Checkpointing saves your state as is, meaning if you happen to scrape by with little to no health, a respawn will bring you back in that condition. This means you'll have to complete long sections of the game starved of your core ressources, or bungling all the way back to a proper savestation to refill. There are energy refills scattered in the world, but the game is incredibly stingy with these drops. I ended up basically never using the explosion attack, since that takes energy too, and why would I spend it on an attack when I might lose out on a critical save later on?The absolute worst part of the game are the escape sequences after every dungeon. These are 95% trial & error, there are parts where you'll die half a dozen times because it just isn't clear where you're supposed to go. I almost gave up on the final one because I could not figure out what it wanted me to do on the final stretch, and keep in mind, you are replaying this ENTIRE section EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. YOU. DIE. At this point, I could probably play the final escape blind.The ability unlocks are also not particularly interesting, and just make number be bigger for the most part. I never ended up finding the dash that is mentioned in the air dash upgrade, which should probably already tell you the game isn't very invested in that side of it.I might just be past tolerating games with instantkill spikes and "Do it again" as their core gameplay-loop, but if you enjoyed that part of early gaming, you're probably gonna like Ori too.

Fantastic experience! Lots of emotive themes and minor details that make this game stand out. Puzzles were challenging at times but not hard enough to distract from the main purpose, and the soundtrack is very well produced. 0 bugs throughout the entire experience, all of the controls become second nature and the abilities you earn are put to the test throughout all stages of the game. This also leads to the point that the game has good replay value when hunting for achievements and extra puzzles. 

My main and only critique is the narration. The makers somewhat failed to choose between showing and telling, and it results in a bit of forced storytelling. This is a minor issue however and I'm sure it won't bother most players whatsoever. 

9/10 Game!!

135241955.review:
TLDR: A visually stunning game marred by mediocre gameplay and a forgettable narrative. I played through the game on Hard, and some of my feedback may not be as applicable on easier difficulties.

PROS: The art and soundtrack are top notch. The opening sequence is fantastic and is very effective at engaging the player emotionally early on. The movement is fluid and satisfying, and the cinematic 'escape' sequences are exhilarating, at least for the first five or so attempts. Among an otherwise basic kit of skills (wall jumping, double jumps, dashes), a few of them felt innovative and refreshing, like the Bash move that allows you to catapult yourself off of enemies and redirect projectiles, which they utilize to great effect in the platforming.

CONS: Ori lacks the subtlety and ambiguity of its counterparts in the Metroidvania genre. Hollow Knight is a prime example, a game where you slowly unravel the mysteries of what happened to the broken world around you, and each new discovery spurs the player onward in search of more answers. Ori places you in a similarly shattered world, but by contrast, every time you happen upon something new or interesting, your Great Value brand Navi companion tells you exactly what took place and why, sucking all mystique and wonder out of it immediately. Good Metroidvanias make you feel like an explorer, and give you the satisfaction of piecing things together as you go along. Ori and the Blind Forest makes you feel more like a tourist:
"Here you'll see the abandoned mountain home of a dead race. They were trying to (spoiler), but then (spoiler) happened and they all died. Here's a half baked gravity puzzle, and then it's on to the next attraction."
"This is the main antagonist. Watch this short cutscene, which will show you their entire backstory and plainly spell out their motivations. Yes, I know we're only 1/3 through the game, but we're on a tight schedule and still have at least three more biomes to herd you through."

The cinematic 'escape' sequences mentioned above could have been really cool moments, but quickly lose their charm. They are littered with obstacles that insta-kill you, and are almost impossible to anticipate until they've already caused you to restart. This turns what would be really cool and memorable moments into exercises of frustration that require you to brute force your way through with trial and error, hitting every snag along the way at least once.

Ori uses insta-kill spike pits as a crutch, and while it offsets this by allowing you to spend energy to create your own save points virtually anywhere you want, it really stifles the movement-centric mechanics of the game. Slightly mis-timing a jump or getting the wrong angle on a Bash often sends you straight back to your last save point, and because the onus of placing them intelligently is left to the player, this can sometimes erase so much progress it made me want to turn the game off. It also forces you to sit through any cutscenes or dialogue you went through since your last save (because nothing says "fun" like re-watching the same unskippable gameplay interruption over and over).

Before anyone dismisses these criticisms with "git gud", I completed the path of pain in HK. I don't say this to brag or claim I'm some god gamer, only to communicate that these complaints are at least in part due to poor game design, and not just a skill issue.

If you're still waiting on Silksong and need something to tide you over, there are certainly worse options out there. Ori isn't a bad game, and if you enjoy the genre you should check it out while its on sale. It certainly has its flaws, but none of them are game breaking.
